debate.para: Debate resumed from the 17th February (vide page 16), on motion by Senator Duncan-Hughes -
That the the following Address-in-Reply to His Excellency the Governor-General's Speech, be agreed to: -
To His Excellency the Governor-General - May it Please Your Excellency:

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

talk.start.para: . - As I stated yesterday in formally submitting this motion, it is an honour to move in this House a motion affirming our loyalty to His Majesty the King. Few men could so well deserve it. His Majesty has been tested, in various ways, to the fullest degree: First of all by the strain of the Great War, later by the after-war difficulties, which in their way have been just as hard to overcome, and also by severe illness. I happened to be in England some three years ago on the day on which the King returned to London after his serious illness, and the demonstration of affection with which he was greeted was most striking. The reception, while not vociferous, was obviously heartfelt. We have good reason to be grateful that we have such a king; and I regard it as a high honour to stand here and move that we affirm our loyalty to him. The Governor-General is an essential link with His Majesty, particularly in these days when he is the King's personal representative. As to the manner of the appointment of the Governor-General I shall have something to say later in some detail; but I now pass on to the Governor-General's Speech itself. Before doing so, however, I wish to express my regret at the passing of Senator Ogden and the Hon. R. W. Foster, who formerly represented the district of "Wakefield in another place. I knew bo,th gentlemen well. Senator Ogden commanded the respect of every one who knew him. He always reminded me of an athlete, wrestling with his thoughts, and overcoming them. The late Mr. Foster was my colleague in another place for six years, until we both suffered defeat at the general election in 1928. During that period the better I knew him the more I learned to admire and like him. Passing now to happier things, I feel sure that I express the feelings of all honorable senators when I say how pleased we are to see Senator Greene in his place again in the Senate after his recent illness, and to congratulate him on again being a member of the Government.

- The Speech of the Governor-General waa commendably brief; I, too, hope to be brief in my remarks concerning it. Since the Senate met in November last an election has been fought. It is, perhaps, neither necessary nor desirable that I should say a great deal about the election itself. The Speech makes it clear that the main issue before the electors was whether Australia should follow a policy based on sound financial principles or should depart from those principles - whether we should follow, the advice of experts, or of amateurs who seek not so much to face the difficulties confronting Australia as to avoid them. We should be grateful that the people of Australia, like the people of the Motherland a few months earlier, made a decision which, in the long run, must prove to be the best for themselves. I say that in no partisan spirit. The Senate has special reason for gratification at the result of the election because of the part it played last year in moulding public opinion on important national questions. The sound principles which are to be followed in the rehabilitation of Australia are set ,out in the Governor-General's Speech. It is obvious that the Government proposes to take the advice of experts in dealing with the many matters which will come before it for decision ; and thus we may hope to find some solution of the problem of unemployment, which, I take it, every member of the Parliaments of Australia desires to see solved as quickly as possible Probably no political party - certainly not that to which I belong - has ever claimed that it i3 possible to do away entirely with unemployment. There is always a minority which is unemployable - men who do not want work. We should be grateful that their number in this country is probably comparatively few. For those who want work we all desire to do our best. The relief of unemployment is one of the greatest internal problems with which the Government will have to wrestle.

speech.para: On the external side for years I have been of the opinion that one of our greatest needs is greater co-operation with other countries. Every day the world is becoming smaller, so that "not only are the members of the British Empire being forced to cooperate more heartily than before, but all the nations of the world are being led to see the necessity for working together. We, in Australia, can no longer regard ourselves as an isolated unit which can do as it likes, particularly in the present state of our finances.

The Speech contained a reference to the balancing of budgets. All honorable senators will agree that it is desirable that efforts to balance the budget should be taken, not only by the Commonwealth, but also by the States. In this connexion I wish to refer to the concession which was made to two States at a recent meeting of the Loan Council, held in Melbourne. When the Loan Council met it was revealed that the estimated receipts for the year would not be realized, and that, consequently, the deficits of several of the States would be greater than was expected. In the light of figures presented to the Loan Council, it was agreed to make a grant or advance to Tasmania and Western Australia. While I am not distressed at the thought of grants being made to the smaller States, I feel that it is unfortunate that our system should be so lopsided that grants should be rendered necessary, largely to compensate for the effect of certain legislation passed by this Parliament. Nov have I any desire to quarrel with the people of Tasmania and Western Australia, who have been hard hit, but I submit that it would have been better had the grants been made by Parliament rather than by the Loan Council. It is undesirable that the Loan Council should become a bargaining ground. I hope that the Leader of the Senate will have something to say on this matter. I suggest also that the making of such grants is not calculated to encourage those States which have made a determined effort to stand up to their obligations under the Premiers agreement. While not claiming every merit for South Australia, I desire to make a comparison of the taxation levied on the people of that State, and that imposed on the taxpayers of the States to "which these advances were made. According to estimates prepared by Treasury experts, the per capita taxation in South Australia is Â£4 2s. lOd. per annum, as compared, with Â£2 4s. lOd. and Â£2 17s. 2d. for Western Australia and Tasmania respectively. I suggest that it is unwise to assist States to meet their deficits in this way. Such action is not likely to make the people of South Australia keener to stand up to the heavy taxation rendered necessary to comply with the Premiers plan when they know that other States, whose people have not been taxed so heavily, can obtain grants from the Commonwealth Government to help them to make up their leeway.

talk.start.para: - Those figures, standing alone, convey nothing. Everything depends upon the ability to pay.

- I" think they may be qualified to a certain extent by local matters which may have assisted in causing the taxation. But the honorable senator surely does not suggest that when South Australia has imposed high taxation, and is going to balance, or nearly balance, its budget, whereas Tasmania has not imposed half that taxation, and is not going to balance its budget, the latter State should have its deficit made good by the Loan Council? As a matter of fact, such a policy would distinctly discourage those States which determined to adhere as closely as possible to what is known as the Premiers plan. Certainly a State would not bo encouraged to impose additional taxation if it believed that 50 per cent, of its deficit would be made good by the Commonwealth Government. I do not wish to overstress this point. I merely add that, in my judgment, it would have been far better if this assistance had been proposed by way of parliamentary grants, which could have been discussed in both Houses of this Parliament.

speech.para: The next point to which I desire to direct attention is the reference, in the Governor-General's Speech, to the financial position of New South Wales. I read in one of the newspapers the other day that when the announcement was made that the Assistant Treasurer (Mr. Bruce) had been appointed as one of the representatives of the Commonwealth at the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa., and later would go to London to act as Resident. Minister there, the Premier of New South Wales said, in referring to his own State's Agent-General in London -

quote.para: Wu must have there a man who will stand up for Australia, and offset the harm that may ha done by a man whose tendency is to apologi/.c for his native land.

speech.para: The plain fact is that we are in the regrettable position of having to apologize for our native land. And the reason why we have to apologize for it is chiefly the attitude which has been adopted by the Premier of New South Wales. It, therefore, comes very badly from Mr. Lang to talk about Mr. Bruce apologizing for Australia. There is, I think, general agreement that no other member of Parliament is so eminently suited for the particular work that has been given to Mr. Bruce as is that right honorable gentleman, not only because for years the details have been very much under his notice, but also because he is well known and liked in Great Britain, and what he says will carry great weight there. He knows the local conditions and the people. I doubt that it would have been possible to get any one whom these respects would discharge so efficiently the responsible duties which will be required of him in London. We all have- to apologize, not for the doings of Australia, in the main, but for the doings of the Leader of the Government in the senior State of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - One would think that the Leaders of other Governments were white-robed angels !

- I do not suggest that. Possibly the honorable senator who has just interjected will endeavour, later, to refute my statements, but before doing so I suggest that if he peruses the English newspapers to bc found in the Library, he will have a clearer insight into the opinion, held overseas, of the Premier of New South Wales. If a man in private life repudiates his obligations, the people with whom lie lias had dealings will have nothing more to do with him in future. The same principle applies in the case of a premier of a State. It is a fact that the Premier of New South Wales lias repudiated, and continues to repudiate, his Government's obligations. In that way, he has jeopardized the financial stability of the Commonwealth, and is doing the greatest possible harm to large sections of his own. State, which are intensely opposed to him and have been throughout. The last federal election made it quite clear that the Premier of New South Wales does not possess the confidence of his own State, and that the rest of Australia is entirely opposed to his financial policy.
- Judging by (be Queensland election results, he must be popular in that State.
- There was no Lang candidate in Queensland.
- And there are not many Nationalist representatives of that State here now.

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon W Kingsmill

talk.start.para: - Order! I remind the Senate that the honorable senator is a new member and is entitled to be heard in silence.

- The Premier of New South Wales does not even enjoy the confidence of the whole of the Labour party in his own State. Senator Daly said yesterday that there was only one Labour party, and that it was a solid party. It is not united, I understand, on the broad question of whether or not it admires Mr. Lang or his policy. If, as Senator Daly has suggested, it is one party, then it must be hydra-beaded, and it speaks at least with many voices. Perhaps this may also be said of other political parties, but rarely has it applied so strongly to any party as it does to the Labour party at the present time. I hope that the Government will do everything that is possible to prevent the Premier of New South. Wales from acting further to the extreme* detriment of the rest of Australia, and: thereby to the rest of the Empire, as wel as indirectly, at least, to the rest of the world.

speech.para: We are told in the Speech, that Mr. Latham, the Minister for External Affairs, will attend the Disarmament Conference at Geneva as a representative of the Commonwealth Government. There are few who do not wish to see the deliberations of that conference attended with the greatest success. Since there is some doubt as to the ability of the League of Nations to give effect to its decisions one should not, at this stage,- say anything which might prevent the Disarmament Conference from being entirely successful. The League has been successful in preventing trouble between member nations in what may be regarded as minor differences, and is now faced with a serious major problem - the dispute between Japan and China. I do not know whether recent events are legally describable as war, but ait all events a considerable number of people on both sides have been killed and, up to the present, the League of Nations has not been successful in preventing an extension of the trouble. We all hope that it will in the near future, because if it should fail, there will be little prospect of success at the Disarmament Conference. I suggest that it is undesirable that we should take sides in the dispute between China and Japan at the present time. There is a tendency, in the press, to criticize Japan for what is thought to be its initiative in the hostilities.

talk.start.para: - Undoubtedly Japan is the aggressor.

- The League of Nations is not satisfied on that point. An endeavour is now being made to ascertain the real causes of the war, but, unfortunately, these things are not so easily discoverable as one might imagine. If the League of Nations does not know what is the reason for the conflict, we in Australia cannot be certain of its cause. For the moment, there5 fore, we might very well withhold judgment, and allow the League to see what it can do. That attitude might be adopted with greater willingness in view of the fact that Japan was an ally of Australia in the late war. I believe that I am right in saying that the first contingent of Australian troops to leave our shores was convoyed by 'ships of the Japanese fleet. Let us, therefore, see to what conclusion the League of Nations can come before we arrive at a definite decision.
- Judging by the last note that it sent to Japan, it would appear that there is not much doubt in the mind of the League.

- That may be so; but it still proposes to have the matter inquired into by a delegation, which may have considerable difficulty, even on the spot, in ascertaining the real cause of the conflict. There may be faults on both sides. It must be extremely difficult to live alongside a country like China, which lias been in a state of turbulence and restlessness for some years, particularly if the question of Russian incitement is involved.

speech.para: A consideration of this matter leads me to say that it surely should furnish an admonition to Australia to have regard to her own defences, which, while the last Government had control of affairs in the Commonwealth, were allowed to get into a deplorable state. It appeared that the Defence Department was singled out for particularly severe treatment. This is perhaps the first occasion upon which the League of Nations has been confronted with a difficulty that it has been unable to surmount, but as the trouble has occurred on our side of the globe, we would be well advised to realize the necessity for seeing that our Defence Department is placed on a proper basis. I feel sure that the Minister for Defence (Senator Pearce) realizes the importance of taking every step that will make for our future safety.

On the question of trade reciprocity I do not propose to say very much to-day. There are many people who believe that tremendous advantages can accrue to Australia without her being called upon to forgo anything. That will be found not to be the case; it will be as much a question of " give ", as it will be tff " take ". Only disappointment awaits those who believe that we are to get everything without surrendering anything in return. At the last Imperial Conference, according to the ex-Prime Minister (Mr. Scullin), all of the dominions were in favour of an agreement along the lines now proposed, but Great Britain stood aloof. As a different Government is now in office in Great Britain, there is ground for hoping and believing that an agreement will be come to at the meeting which is to be held at Ottawa during the present year.

On the general question of the tariff it is not easy to say very much at the present moment, because the reference to it in the Governor-General's speech is couched in rather general terms, and naturally so. I say frankly that it is not quite so strong as I should like to have seen it, and that it is hard to determine exactly what is meant. The phrase used is - " Subject to certain alterations which will be proposed ". If those alterations prove successful, well and good. It will be necessary to see what is proposed before we can be certain that the alterations are sufficiently extensive. Every honorable senator knows that the predicament of the primary producer has become in most cases almost, and in. many cases quite, impossible. That applies to practically the whole of our primary products, from the greatest to the smallest. The primary producer has been receiving wretchedly low prices, and for at least a year or two has experienced adverse seasons. In addition, he has had to contend against the general financial stringency which has had general application throughout Australia. Then also, he has been handicapped hy the tremendously high prices which, as a result of the tariff, he has had to pay for the secondary commodities that he has been obliged to purchase. In this respect, the Senate can render substantial assistance. The tariff has been pushed to a perfectly absurd point. I can assure honorable senators that for several years the farmers in practically every branch of primary production have passed through very lean times. I hope I shall find in the Senate some who feel as I do - that the primary producer is essentially the backbone of this country, and that we must make it possible. for him to carry on. Consequently, I hope that the alterations to be proposed will embrace some at least of the lines that are essential to primary production. I trust further that the duties will be considerably reduced on oregon, which vitally concerns housebuilding in at least three of the States. Within recent years they have been advanced tremendously, and they became so severe that they aroused the criticism even of members of the Labour party.

talk.start.para: - Is not timber a primary product?

- What protection, may I ask the honorable senator, is given to the man who produces wool? Is he protected to the extent of GOO per cent, of the value of his product? Why should timber receive a protection amounting to 600 per cent, when all the taxation is borne by the wool and wheat industries? I am not a free-trader; I believe in a reasonable amount of protection, and consider that some duty may be imposed on oregon; but I cannot subscribe to such high duties as those that are at present in force. At the last election the people of South Australia voted very largely on this issue. Wherever I went in the country, I found that the tariff was becoming a more vital question than it had ever been before, simply because the people felt that they could not carry on unless the burden was somewhat alleviated. Therefore, I trust that there will be no unnecessary delay in dealing with this matter, and that the alterations which are to be proposed immediately will be substantial and not confined to a few minor items.

speech.para: One other thing that I hope the Government will do is to act at once upon reports of the Tariff Board already supplied. The pigeon-holes of the Customs office must be filled with reports from that board, and I suggest that it would be a very excellent thing if some of those which have been submitted during the last two years were adopted as quickly as possible without waiting for further reports upon the items covered by them. It is abundantly clear, if only from the annual reports of the board itself, that the late Government did not in quite a number of cases follow the recommendations of the board. Of course Ministers are quite within their rights in submitting to Parliament tariff schedules which differ from those recommended by the Tariff Board - that body was constituted as an- advisory board; the last decision rests with the Minister - but although the late Government may not have seen fit to adopt recommendations of the Tariff Board, it will be quite competent for the present Government to do so.

I shall not touch upon the question of constitutional alterations, except to say that I hope that suggested alterations we have heard about for years past will bc made very soon. At any rate, I hope that action in this respect will not be postponed until next year. The time for constitutional reform is now over-ripe. This country is creaking and groaning under the imperfections of its constitution. I have no particular desire to be critical, but the experience of the last 30 years, and the immense development of the Commonwealth have rendered many changes necessary. I trust that a convention will be held at an early date at which the matter may be discussed as between the different States. The mere fact that State Premiers are frequently called upon to rush to and from and meet one another in Melbourne or Sydney shows how extremely difficult it is to carry on under the existing Constitution.

I take it that for the next session or two the Senate will be faced, as indeed it was last year, owing to the difficulties of the country, with unpleasant tasks which it will have to perform, but I have not the least doubt that in whatever it does it will be fortified by the recent expression of opinion at the general election. With the exception of Queensland, the Commonwealth as a whole has shown very clearly what its feeling is.

Apparently a revolution may be anything; it may be a violent one or a peaceful one. There is frequent talk of revolution in Australia, although I must confess I have not seen many signs of a revolutionary spirit in South Australia of late. It is merely talk, but in this connexion I came across some words the other day written by a great British historian in 1864, which it struck me might very well be taken into consideration by those who talk glibly of revolution in any shape or form. These words were -

quote.para: We should draw no horoscopes; we should expect little, for what we expect -will not come to pass. Revolutions, reformations - those vast movements into which heroes and saints have flung themselves, in the belief that they were the dawn of the milennium - have not borne the fruit which they looked for. Milenniums are still far away. These great convulsions leave the world changed, perhaps improved, but not improved as the actors in them hoped it would be.

speech.para: Those who talk of revolution would do we'll to bear in mind the history of the French revolution, and the fate of some of the leaders of that revolution. They might also remember how, for a brief time, revolution merged into the splendours - and miseries - of the Napoleonic era. It is easy to talk of revolution, but I do not think we are on the eve of one in Australia. Indeed it is abundantly clear from the result of the recent election how the promoters of any revolution would fare at the hands of the people of this country.

talk.start.para: . - I congratulate, if I may do so with propriety, Senator Duncan-Hughes on the temperateness and clearness with which he has carried out the task entrusted to him, and I rise to second the motion he 'has moved. I join with him 'completely in expressing the "pleasure and the honour I feel at being associated with a motion which expresses our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign,. and thanks His Majesty's person a'l representative in Australia for the speech which he has delivered to Parliament.

speech.para: I also associate myself with the remarks Senator Duncan-Hughes has made upon the death since our last meeting of our friend and colleague, Senator Ogden.

Coming to the Speech delivered by His Excellency the 'Governor-General, I desire to offer a few observations on a subject touched upon by the mover of the motion, the position which His Excellency occupies to His Majesty the King under the new regime. The first effects of the inauguration of the new system we witnessed yesterday when, for the first time in the history of the Commonwealth, with stately ceremony, this Parliament was opened by a Governor-General born and bred in Australia. It will not be taken I am sure as in any sense disrespectful to His Excellency the Governor-General if we consider, entirely in the abstract, the possible effects of this new regime. Of course, there as no reference to it in the speech His Excellency read, but it is suggested and, if I may say so, becomes relevant, by the very delivery -of the speech. For many years during the history, not merely of the Commonwealth .but of the constituent parts of the Commonwealth also, we have had a system binding us 'closely to His Majesty the King, our loyalty to whom we are expressing in this motion to-day; und I do not think that .any one .can say that, so far as the practical working of that system is concerned, it has ever failed us. I realize that it may he in one sense almost as improper to praise His Excellency the Governor-General as to censure him, hut we are extremely fortunate, if I may say so, again with respect, that we have among us to-day as the typical head of the nation, a man with the outstanding qualifications of our present Governor-General. The system, however, and it is that with which I am dealing, must he judged, not by its happy -accidents, but by its general tendencies, lt may he that it is a happy accident that we have had placed at our head a man with the outstanding qualifications of the present Governor-General, but it seems to me that under this new system there is a danger of the high, exalted, and impartial office of the Governor-General being in the long course of ages reduced into something of the unpleasantness 'of party politics. Parliament lays the foundation of the future, and must look into the ages. Blackstone laid it down that we should be unwilling to change our laws, and, although there is no reference in the speech to any future intention on the part of the Government in regard to this matter, I hope that it will -be recognized that the system under which we have lived up to the present time has worked admirably. It has kept us in close touch with the heart of the Empire, and has been entirely to the advantage of Australia. The one visible link which now exists between the various parts of the Empire and the heart of the Empire is the Governor or Governor-General, as the case may be, but in course of time and with the growth of a spirit of self-conscious nationhood there is a natural tendency to assert an independence which we enjoy for all practical purposes but which, perhaps, does not exist in the strict letter of the law. The presence of a Governor-General remains, as I have said, almost the sole link there is between the parts of the Empire and the heart of the Empire, more particularly since the framing of the Statute of Westminster. It is, I understand, not yet passed. That statute may have extraordinarily great consequences on the relations between the parts of the Empire and the heart of the Empire, and I commend to honorable senators an article which appeared last Monday in the Melbourne Argus, in the course of which a competent constitutional authority said -

quote.para: Are we losing our British citizenship? In critical situations St. Paul found his Roman citizenship stand to him like a bodyguard; and from his day to ours the; citizenship of a great empire has often proved a. priceless possession. The gift of British citizenship, valid throughout the Empire and elsewhere, has been ours from birth. It is in danger of disappearing. It rests upon British statutes, which have linen outside the reach of dominion legislation. But when the Statute of Westminster becomes law, the paramountcy of those statutes will have gone beyond recall, and each dominion will have the power to pass legislation refusing the rights of citizenship within its borders to the peoples of other dominions and of Great Britain itself, except on such conditions as the dominion law imposes. There is no theoretical limit to the severity of those conditions.
When the report upon which the Statute of Westminster was founded was under discussion in the Irish Parliament, the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. McGilligun) said -

A national, hereafter, of this State, if we pass certain legislation, which may be passed at any moment, will mean a person whom we admit to citizenship in this State under whatever conditions we like to impose.

This is the first indication of the way in which Australians may find themselves stripped piecemeal of their present wide-ranging British citizenship, and reduced practically to the status of aliens in other parts of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

speech.para: As a humble member of the Senate, I venture the opinion that if the Statute of Westminster were not proceeded with beyond the stage it has now reached the people of Australia would not feel that they had lost anything.

I now pass to the Speech itself, and in what I have to say I hope I shall be brief. There are some who may consider that the Speech is lacking in anything very definite in the nature of governmental proposals.

talk.start.para: - Hear, hear!

- One of my honorable friends opposite says, "Hear, hear " ! No doubt there will be others who will adopt the view expressed in that interjection. But the very reason which would cause some honorable senators to be dissatisfied with the Speech is one, at any rate, of the reasons which causes me in a measure to be satisfied with it. I am aware that those who look to Parliaments to cure the ills of the world will think the Speech disappointing.
- They will be disappointed, too.

- That may be. As a matter of fact, I look forward to the day when the Speech of the Governor-General, at the opening of Parliament, will not contain notes of exuberance, because of the many projected measures which it discloses, but rather an apology for the fact that it has become necessary in our ever-expanding social organism to pass such legislation. I say that for the reason that every act of Parliament that is passed means some curtailment of human liberty. I am one of these who believe with Edmund Burke - whatever my friends opposite may think - that liberty is a good to be enlarged, and not an evil to be diminished. Therefore, I do not look with approval at any Governor-General's Speech - and I have in the course of my life read a great many, if I have not heard them - that contains a long list of measures. My view is that too much has been attempted by Parliaments in the past. We have attributed, in large measure, the prosperity which in the goodness of providence we have enjoyed, partly to the laws we have passed, partly to our own excellent qualities, and partly to the richness of the country which we inhabit, whereas the simple fact is that, so far as we have progressed, we have done so mainly, not because of, but in spite of the laws we have enacted. The whole tendency of our laws - and it is a growing tendency - is to restrict more and more, human liberty. I am one of those who believe that the less we restrict human -liberty the better it must be for the community as a whole. It does not follow that because, when we were enjoying prosperity, we were able to make progress in spite of our laws, we shall bc able to do so in times of depression such as those through which we are now passing. The less we attempt in the way of legislation for the regeneration of this country at this critical period, the better it will be .for the country itself. Therefore, I rejoice that the Government, true to the pledges ' which its members gave on the hustings, is not setting out a long list of panaceas for all the evils under which this country labours.

speech.para: There is a reference in the Speech to the fact that the New Year has opened with a healthier and brighter feeling in the community. I believe that there is such a feeling in the community. If it is so, it is quite clear that it has not arisen from anything which the Government has done, since it has not had time to do anything. If has arisen from the mere psychological fact, that a government has been returned in which the people have some confidence. It lias arisen because the people in control of industry now know where they stand. They do not say "Now we have a government which, by its legislation, will lift this country to a higher level ", but " Now we have a government which by its legislation, will not hamper us in our endeavours to lift the country to a higher level ".

I believe there is very little that this Government can do to help this country forward except to exercise rigid economy in governmental affairs, and cut down the expenses of government as much as possible. I am not to be taken as suggesting that there should be dismissals of public servants or anything of that nature. Economies can be exercised without inflicting hardship on those who serve the Government, and serve it loyally; but if it should be necessary, I am sure that public servants like private citizens will be quite willing to bear their full share of whatever is required of them. The people have shown in the attitude they took to the great conversion loan, that they are prepared to make sacrifices. That being so, it is the duty of the Government to honour its part of the undertaking embodied in the Premiers plan, and carry out a policy which will succeed, as I hope it will, in very little time, in the proper balancing of budgets. It must be evident to every one that budgets' can be balanced only by increasing the national income in some way or by reducing expenditure. Every one must realize now that we have reached the limit, so far as income from taxation is concerned. Indeed I believe that what this country is suffering from at present - it may be quite necessary that it should so suffer - is the enormous weight of taxation which its citizens have to bear.
I am also pleased, as I am sure every one else will be, at the passage in His Excellency's Speech which states that -

My advisers, however, are satisfied that there is a general determination to adhere to the plan of financial and economic rehabilitation which has already produced a favorable effect upon the position of Australia.
Like every citizen of Australia worthy of the name, I regret that one State and that the most populous-

talk.start.para: - And the richest.

- And the richest, is the one that should have failed at this critical juncture. The material consequences of that failure are bad enough, and as the Speech says, may involve the whole Commonwealth in financial disaster. But the moral consequence - if one can separate the moral from the material - may be even a great deal worse. We are lineal descendants of the British race. In these outer marches of the Empire we are entrusted with the upholding of the reputation which our forefathers across the seas have built up and maintained through the long ages, and it must have come as a painful shock to everybody of right feeling at any rate to learn that for the first time in the glorious history of the British race, the word of British people had been dishonoured. If anything we feel more humiliated by the reasons that have been put forward for that dishonouring. If in the past we have had to defend a principle or a military position, we have done so by putting men in the firing line. This is the first time it has been sought to defend a position otherwise indefensible by putting babies in the firing line. It was at the close of the Boer War that an explore Chancellor, speaking in the House of Lords, quoted some lines which are particularly appropriate to-day -

speech.para: In all the ills the years have brought,
In all the grief we bore,
We sighed, we wept, we toiled, we fought,
We never blushed before.

We have had some reason to blush at the course of events in the most populous and, as Senator Lynch has said, the richest State in the Commonwealth, which should have set an example to the rest of Australia but has so completely failed to do so.

I am not wanting in sympathy towards that large section of the people in New South Wales who feel this humiliation as much as we do, but there is a lesson to be learned from the situation. It is only fifteen months since rival policies were put before the people of that great State. On the one hand, there was a policy which said " We have nothing to offer you. There is a road of sacrifice to be travelled and we must traverse it. Return us and we will lead you along that road in the hope that some day we shall emerge into the sunlight." The rival policy was this: "Return us and we will borrow as we borrowed before. We will complete all the uncompleted public works. We will restore all reductions that have been made in salaries." The people - speaking of the people as a whole - listened to the voice of the tempter and returned to power the man who made that promise.
SenatorGreene. - He also promised to find employment for the unemployed.

talk.start.para: - And the number of unemployed has grown steadily from that day to this.

speech.para: The lesson to be learned is that when the way of sacrifice stands before us we must face it. We do not solve problems by evading them. We do not solve them by dishonesty of conduct or words. Unfortunately, the people of New South Wales will sooner or later have to face the position, and the sacrifices will be all the greater by reason of the fact that they did not face them when they might have done so.

talk.start.para: - The United Australia party made numerous promises in their advertisements.
- I do not think any promises were ever so blatantly made or so flagrantly dishonoured as were the promises made by the Government which, to its discredit, at present rules New South Wales.

speech.para: I pass on to other items mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech. One of the things that are regarded by His Excellency's advisers as of cardinal importance is that every possible step should be taken to stimulate private enterprise. I have already indicated that private enterprise can be stimulated by a negative policy. I think that some of the restrictions placed by the law upon industry will have to be removed. I realize that some honorable senators opposite will say that I am attacking wages and am in favour of reducing the Australian standard of living. On previous occasions in this chamber I have asked what is the standard of living of the nearly 400,000 men who are walking our streets and roads, not knowing where their next meal is to be obtained.

talk.start.para: - We cannot improve their condition by adding to their burden.

- No; but we may improve their condition by making less rigid the social system under which they live and work. An honorable senator who is no longer with us, once deprecated that employers and employed should have " an open go ". I take it that that means that honest men on the one side should be free to negotiate with honest men on the other side as to the terms upon which they shall work, and be worked for. Personally, I do not believe that any dire consequences would follow such negotiations. Many of us fail to realize the extent to which socialism has been installed in our midst, by reason of some of the provisions of the Arbitration Act.
- Is it not right to protect the honest men on both sides from the dishonest few on both sides?
- Yes. The first duty of any government is to protect its citizens; its last duty is to interfere in the private relations of the honest men in all classes of the community.

speech.para: Senator Duncan-Hughes referred to the talk of revolution. It may be, as the honorable senator stated, that the recent elections showed the real temper of the people of Australia. Nevertheless, I remind those who are so anxious to restore prosperity to this country, that nothing is more calculated to retard the return of prosperity than is the talk of revolution and violence, which we hear in so many quarters to-day. Nothing will bring Australia back to prosperity more quickly than will confidence in the stability and honesty of its several governments.

I pass by the subject of disarmament mentioned in the Speech, 'not because 1 regard is as unimportant, but because we may soon have an opportunity to discuss it in this chamber. 1 come now to two other matters which, in my opinion, are intimately connected - the Ottawa conference and the tariff. The Governor-General's Speech states -

quote.para: Owing to world-wide depression, the volume of world trade lias declined, and the struggle for markets is becoming still more intense.

speech.para: I associate myself with the previous speaker in the view that, in the event of there being a struggle for markets, we in Australia must realize that the concessions must not be one-sided. We must realize that trade is mutual; if we hope to obtain markets for our goods in other countries, we must be prepared to allow some of their products to come here. I am entirely in accord with the remarks of Senator Duncan-Hughes as to the importance of the Ottawa conference. With him I agree that something in the nature of reciprocal Empire trade seems to offer the greatest possibilities for the future. At the same time, I submit that if it is to the advantage of the several parts of the Empire to reciprocate in trade matters, it is also to the advantage of all countries to reciprocate in trade generally. Let lis, for a moment, consider our trade with France. Each year France buys from us wool to the value of about Â£11,000,000. Remembering the importance of wool to Australia, we ought to be exceedingly careful not to do anything which might endanger our wool trade with France. Every year Australia has to pay to other countries about Â£30,000,000 in interest, and only now are the people generally beginning to realize that that interest can be paid only by our exports, which are chiefly wool and wheat, together with a few other primary products. If we do nothing to discourage that export trade, I feel sure that it will look after itself.

Coming now to the tariff, I notice that attempts are being made to make it appear that the tentative tariff of 1929, as amended on several occasions since its introduction, embodies Australia's protective policy, and that any one who does not accept it is making an attack on the protective system of this country. While I make no such attack, I, like Senator Duncan-Hughes, maintain that the tariff has gone to absurd limits, and has had woeful consequences to those engaged in primary production. Every economist who has spoken on the subject of the present world depression, has called attention to the effect on trade of the tariffs of various countries. That the conflicting tariffs of the world have reduced international trade almost to vanishing point is patent to everyone. All economists are agreed that consequences have resulted from high tariffs which were not foreseen by any one, and that the present condition of world affairs is largely the result of restrictive tariffs. There are some who contend that the last stronghold of freetrade has fallen now that Great Britain has to some extent surrendered her policy of freetrade. It has been stated that Mr. Neville Chamberlain was moved almost to tears at the introduction of a tariff which his father had foreshadowed early in this century. It is now submitted that the course of events in Great Britain proved that Mr. Joseph Chamberlain was right,' and that those who opposed him were wrong. In considering this matter, we must not forget that Britain has passed through the greatest war the world has known. No other country has presented such a spectacle of financial stability as has Great Britain since the beginning of the war; she financed herself and other nations as well. To-day we live in a changing world; and it may be that Great Britain has had to adopt a measure of protection in order to adjust her balance of trade. To some it may appear that the period since the close of the war has been long; but judged historically, Ave are only now suffering the effects of the war. Experience has shown that at the close of all great wars there has been a period of spurious activity, followed by a period of depression. That has happened in recent years; the spurious activity was so great that the depression has been deeper. We shall, however, live through the depression. When our representatives go to Ottawa, I hope that they will not go in a spirit of selfish bargaining. Bargaining there must be, but Australia should realize that there must be " give " as well as " take that trade must be reciprocal. We should be prepared to do what we can not only for Australia, but also for the other parts of the Empire of which we are proud to form a part.

I regret to have to disagree with Senator Duncan-Hughes regarding the need for constitutional changes. I do not believe that conditions in Australia call for any serious alteration in our Constitution, either now ot in the immediate future. I submit that any apparent defects have arisen not from the Constitution itself, but from those who have been engaged to work it. In other words, the defect is not in the machine, but in the machinist. The extent to which the Constitution has apparently failed, because it has led to some ill-will within the Commonwealth, is due to the attempts made by Parliament to do too much, due, as a learned French economist once said, to the efforts of the people to convert Parliament House into the battle ground of everybody's dreams and everybody's covetousness. Take, for example, our high protective policy. When Australian manufacturers put forward proposals for high duties, do they think of Australia as a whole, or only of themselves? When the industrialists in our large cities ask for higher duties for themselves, are they thinking of the struggles of the farmers in the outback places ? Similarly, when Queensland unites to extract a sugar bounty from the rest of Australia, are its people thinking of Australia or only of Queensland? Honorable senators will recollect that the Navigation Act was the outcome of an unholy alliance, in which the shipowners said to the industrialists " Give us the coastal trade to ourselves, and you can have your arbitration awards." When that alliance was entered into, were the parties to it thinking how the Navigation Act would ruin Tasmania?

talk.start.para: - Tasmania is a long way from being ruined.
- I hope so. Tasmania is a rich country which ought to be a model of quiet prosperity.
- So it would be, if left alone.

- I agree with the honorable senator that had Tasmania been given fair treatment by the rest of Australia, it would now be a prosperous State. Once we, as a people, learn to shape our legislation in the interests of the whole of Australia, rather than of its several parts, we shall hear less of proposals for constitutional changes. I remind those who are demanding these constitutional alterations that although the Constitution provides for its amendment, it is not possible to make any change that will not give more power to the central government. And the very persons who are calling for constitutional changes are those who object that already the central government has too much power or, at any rate, is exhibiting too much activity. When asking for constitutional changes they should bear these things in mind. There is some casual reference to the subject in the Speech and to the want of time to fully consider what amendments should be made; but while sympathizing with Senator DuncanHughes, I hope we shall not hear anything further of constitutional changes during the lifetime of this Parliament.

speech.para: I conclude by endorsing the hope expressed in the last paragraph of the Speech that Divine Providence may guide our country. I have every confidence that if the people of Australia will realize that we still have a great country, and that the greatest asset any country or people can have is its reputation, we shall in due time emerge from the deep depression through which we are passing. I second the motion.

talk.start.para: .- I congratulate the mover of the motion (Senator Duncan-Hughes) and the seconder (Senator Brennan) upon their successful discharge of a difficult task, namely, that of infusing a little enthusiasm into their remarks in support of the Government's policy, or want of policy. The Speech of the Governor-General is wholly lacking in inspiration. The primary purpose of such a document is to give information to the people of the legislative proposals of the Government, but the Speech delivered to the Senate yesterday contains not even a glimmer of light. It is true that it tells us that the Government intends to take certain action with regard to national finance and unemployment, which are so inter-related that they cannot be separated ; but both were receiving the earnest attention of the previous administration. The late Government brought down proposals to improve the finances of this country and to reduce unemployment. The plan to which the Government was working was the product of eminent experts representing the Commonwealth and State Governments. It had many faults, but undoubtedly it did something to put Australia into a sounder financial position, and I feel sure that, in time, it would have brought this country out of its present difficulties. That plan was working satisfactorily under the previous administration, but unfortunately, because of a hostile majority in this chamber, we were not in a position to give full effect to our policy. The present Ministry is not faced with that difficulty. Commanding, as it does, a majority in both Houses it will be able to give legislative effect to any proposal it thinks fit to bring forward.

speech.para: The causes which led to the change of government at the last election are explainable. The people were becoming desperate owing to the increase in unemployment. They realized that, as the Government was ham-strung in the Senate it was unable to do what it set out to do, so we may assume that they resolved to give this new Government, which boasted so much" of its capacity to pull the country out of its troubles, an opportunity to do so. I can only hope that it will manage the affairs of the Commonwealth with greater ability than was shown by the Bruce-Page Government. The present situation is a very desperate one. Our army of unemployed is increasing continuously; it has increased even since the return of the present Government to power, and despite the alleged confidence of the people in its ability to restore financial stability.

talk.start.para: - To what extent has unemployment increased since the elections ?

- I am not in a position to say precisely, but I have read in the newspapers that several establishments have recently closed down. Only a day or two ago it was reported that in one industry alone there had been an increase of 3,000 unemployed persons.

speech.para: There is reference in the Speech to the projected mission to England of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr. Bruce), who will act as Resident Minister in London after attending the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa. His object, I assume, will be to inspire more confidence in the minds of those financiers in Great Britain, who sometimes oblige us with loans. I can only hope that he will be more successful than in the last year of his Government's administration when, as we know, it failed ignominiously in its attempts to raise further money in London.

talk.start.para: - Lang could not be blamed for that failure.

- No; Mr. Lang had not then come into the firing line. It seems to me that the Assistant Treasurer is not the best emissary the Government could have selected for the purpose in view, and I am afraid that, having regard to the experience of the Bruce-Page Government, any overtures which he may make for financial assistance in London will meet with a poor response.

speech.para: The Government, in its effort to win the last election, placarded the country v with posters suggesting that its success at the polls would mean the end of unemployment. As a matter of fact, one election placard illustrated an army of unemployed marching back to the factories, workshops and mines, with smiling faces and hands in their pockets feeling for the money which, no doubt, they hoped to get on pay day. But this Government has not indicated any definite plan by which it will relieve unemployment. The previous administra- tration had no doubt as to its ability to finance its proposals, and it would have been successful but for the obstruction which it encountered in this chamber.

One paragraph in the Speech makes mention of the cessation of Commonwealth public works and, because finance is difficult, it is proposed to abolish not only the PublicWorks Committee, but also the Public Accounts Committee, a very important body, which has rendered very useful service to the Commonwealth. Both, indeed, have done good service.

talk.start.para: - There is no works programme for the committee.

- The Scullin Government had works in contemplation, and knew how to finance them. This Government has no cure for unemployment because it is unable to provide finance. No one will deny that many useful and reproductive works could be undertaken if financial provision could be made for them. How does the Government intend to absorb the growing army of unemployed? It is useless to talk about giving relief, if the means whereby it is to be given cannot be shown. The last Government propounded a certain policy, but honorable senators who now sit opposite refused to allow it to be put in operation. There is plenty of work of a profitable nature waiting to be done in Australia, but the money to carry it out must first bo found. From what source is it to be obtained? The Governor-General's Speech does not contain even the glimmer of a proposal; all that the Government apparently intends to do is to send a Minister to the Old Country for the purpose of raising a loan, despite the fact that on two previous occasions a similar application was rejected.
- What cure would the honorable senator prescribe?

- The cure suggested by the last Government was an alteration of the financial system of this country. Had that been given effect, the Government would have been able so to arrange the affairs of Australia that sufficient money would have been available to absorb the army of unemployed in profitable public works.
- They would have been paid with " shin plasters ".

- The country is being financed with " shin plasters " at the present time, in the shape of cheques on accounts that are overdrawn. The cheque of a private individual can be described more truly as a "shin plaster " than can a fiduciary note, because it has the backing of only one individual, whereas the other has behind it the whole of the assets of the country. Honorable senators opposite argue that Australia has not sufficient internal credit to carry out any undertaking, and that it must borrow abroad. It is time that the people realized the soundness of their credit, and the wealth of their assets, and insisted upon the affairs of this country being financed without resort to the foreign money lender, from whom so many millions have been borrowed in the past that, as the seconder of the motion for the adoption of the Address-in-Reply stated, our interest commitments at the present time total some Â£30,000,000 a year. Until there is in office a government which recognizes the practicability of using the credit resources of the country for the financing of public works, it will not be possible to do much towards relieving the unemployed. The prices obtained for our primary products have been affected by the depression that has operated not only in Australia, but also throughout the world. We have not been able to sell our produce to other countries to nearly the extent we desired because their army of unemployed is as great proportionately as ours, and that has had the effect of lessening the purchasing power of the nations. Until the unemployed problem is solved, there will be no hope of solving the problem of prices, or any of the other problems that so acutely affect Australia at the present time. The first essential is to place at work those who wield the pick and shovel, so that they may have something to spend. They are the foundation of our social structure, and upon their stability depends the strength of the edifice that is erected.
- Surely that is the responsibility of the States!

- It is the responsibility of the whole of the people of this country . Under present conditions, I admit that it is more the responsibility . of the States than of the Commonwealth. If, however, the alterations to the Constitution that are foreshadowed are made - and in my opinion they should he - it will become the responsibility of the whole of Australia. The men who lay the foundations of the social structure of this country must be able to obtain work whenever they want it. When they cease to earn, the whole edifice must topple down.

speech.para: According to some authorities, the way in which loans have been made to the States of Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania, is illegal. That may or may not be so; but in certain circumstances which could not be foreseen and provided against, a government would be justified even in acting illegally if it were necessary to prevent the collapse of any State or States. Consequently, I do not quibble at the slight measure of assistance that has been given to the States to which I have referred. The position in New South Wales for which the people of that State have been blamed-

talk.start.para: - Not the people.

- Mr. Lang is no more powerful than the majority of individuals, and cannot take any action unless he has the support of the majority of the elected representatives of the people. This, however, is a matter upon which honorable senators from New South Wales are more qualified' to speak, and to them I shall leave it.

speech.para: The Speech of the Governor-General lays it down that the best way to relieve unemployment is to encourage private enterprise. How is private enterprise to be encouraged when the Government will not itself tackle the problem, or release the credits that are necessary to enable employment to be provided by private individuals?

talk.start.para: - What credits are there to be released ?
- There are many business people in this country who can tell the honorable senator what an extension of credit means.

speech.para: Reference is made in the Speech to the question of disarmament. There are some men in the world who strongly oppose disarmament; but it gives me pleasure to think that the great majority of the people of every country, particularly those who are called upon to do any fighting that has to be done, will welcome any steps that may be taken in that direction. They are convinced, as I am, that the greatest menace to the peace of any country is the continual building up of armaments by any nation. Such a policy, in my opinion, was responsible for the last war. This question is being closely examined by the people of the world, now that the heat engendered by the last conflict has somewhat died down and a calm review of all the circumstances is possible. Germany was blamed for the last outbreak, because for 40 years she had been building up armaments of various kinds, the argument advanced being that it was her ambition to conquer the world. I have no brief for Germany ; but I ask honorable senators to consider for a moment her geographical situation. She had on one of her borders the Russian nation, of which she was as much afraid as it was possible for one country to be of another. Upon another border, she had the Balkan States and Austria, and on the other side there was France. Consequently, she was hemmed in on all sides by nations which she considered were her bitter enemies, and a menace to the liberty and the welfare of her people. In all probability she armed in order to protect herself. This caused alarm in the minds of the people of other countries, and gave rise to the belief that there was a deliberate intention on the part of Germany to cause injury to the rest of the world. I, in common with other honorable senators, welcome the attention that is being devoted by some of the greatest < minds in the world to the possibility of doing away with what is most likely to incite trouble between one nation and another. When war occurs, people who have no animosity towards each other kill merely in order that they themselves may survive. They are hurled into the conflict without being given time to consider the consequences, and it is only when the calamity has been perpetrated that the full extent of its effect is felt.

According to the Speech of the Governor-General, it is proposed to abolish the Committee of Public Accounts. I have not had the experience of working on that committee, but from what I have been told I believe that it has performed very valuable work for Australia. It may be said of the Public Works Committee that it has cost a good deal of money; but that has occurred only while it ha3 been functioning.

talk.start.para: - It saved the country a lot of money.

- I know that it did. It has always justified its existence. I say the same of the Committee of Public Accounts, which has been a very much less costly body. It may not have saved as much public money as the Public Works Committee, but it certainly has done magnificent work. Other honorable senators who have had experience on it can enlighten the Senate regarding the nature of its operations.

speech.para: Senator Brennan expressed a desire to revert to the conditions that existed at the time of " the open go " in industry. I do not know whether that gentleman has had much experience of the operation of the system and of its effect upon the people of this country. If he has had, he should be very reluctant to advocate a reversion to anything like a similar state of affairs. " The open go " did not mean that an honest man on one side met an honest man on the other and came to an agreement to maintain- harmonious relations. What happened was that the worst element in the country ran its affairs. The conditions were those that were dictated by the greatest scoundrels, who were utterly indifferent to the welfare of- the country. There was a long and a bitter fight to clip the wings of this element in the community, and to bring into existence a system that would enable honest men on both side3 to meet each other and settle their differences.
Senator- Payne. - Is there not some trouble now on that point?

talk.start.para: - I know that there is. No matter what machinery there may be in existence for the settlement of disputes, it will never function satisfactorily because there is always the element of discontent in human nature. But that i9 the element which has always made for the progress of the human race. Had our forefathers remained quiescent, contented with their lot, we should not to-day be in possession of all the advantages of civilization we enjoy. The policy of the " open go " will get us nowhere. It is practically the policy of a return to the open ditch, from which our forefathers emerged.

speech.para: Many attempts have been made to alter our Constitution to give the people greater control of the affairs of this country. There is a conflict of opinion as to how the Constitution should be altered. I would give the Commonwealth absolute power to do what it wanted, which, of course, would mean the wiping out of State Parliaments. An alteration to bring about that result would confer tremendous advantages on the people. I can never understand why the people cannot be trusted. With their very existence at stake surely they can be trusted to take care of their own country. As a matter of fact with the people in control the country would be safer than it is under the present system of restricted control.

I do not intend to say any more. I know that Ministers are anxious to get to work to clear up the mess they claim they have inherited from the late Government. I shall afford them every opportunity to get busy. Relief will, probably, come sooner to the people when " the dingoes are not howling ". I suggest that we can complete our immediate business and adjourn to enable another place to send us down some work to do. Any scheme which will give relief to the unemployed, and will improve the financial condition of the country, will receive the wholehearted support of the Opposition. The more speedily the Government gets busy to bring about that end, the better the Opposition will be pleased.

talk.start.para: [5.10]. - I congratulate the mover and seconder of the motion for the Address-in-Reply on their thoughtful and sound speeches. The sobriety of their utterances reflects the sobriety of the policies they endorse. They commented favorably on what the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) regards as a defect, the absence of any promise of a long legislative programme. I may say at once that the Government has deliberately taken up that attitude towards its activities in the coming year because it believes that it will be a year of great difficulty. The main theme of the Speech is that there should be every attempt to live within the Premiers plan. Although we have only just come into office, it is already obvious to us that if we are to live within the Premiers plan there must be further economies in governmental expenditure. It has, so far, been impossible for us tc look adequately into the question of how those economies are to be effected, but if honorable senators will pause for a minute to consider the subject, they will realize that the task is one which should be undertaken solely by Ministers. Official staffs cannot undertake it. Of course they will loyally carry out any instructions they get from Ministers, but if we are to have real economy, it must be brought about by the considered action of Ministers as the result of an intense and continually applied search into various avenues of expenditure and a determination as to which of those avenues should be cut down.

speech.para: Short as has been our experience in this Government, we have already seen certain directions in which we believe the cost of government can be cut down. One of them already suggested is the suspension of the two committees associated with the cost of Parliament. Many no doubt could advance reasons why the Public "Works Committee and the Public Accounts Committee should continue to function, but I think that the majority of honorable senators will agree that during this time of great financial stress we can very well carry on without them. They are not to be abolished; they are merely to be suspended. If either branch of the" legislature considered that any matter should be the subject of inquiry it would bo quite easy to set up a select committee at a comparatively small cost to deal with it. I think the overwhelming body of feeling in both chambers is that at a time like this it is wise to suspend the expenditure upon these two committees.

Another reason for a short legislative programme is that our financial condition is serious in regard not only to government expenditure, but also in regard to the position of Commonwealth and State finance, both in Australia and overseas. The active cooperation of the Commonwealth and the

States is absolutely essential to avoid serious trouble, if not disaster, and surely, at a time like this, when we are grappling with these questions it would not be wise to have Parliament sitting and dealing with intensified programmes of legislation. It is indeed a time to devote to the consideration of the measures which must be taken by the Commonwealth and the States to meet the crises which will arise within the next twelve months. It is certainly not a time to be dealing with legislative matters that can wait until we are out of the storm. The storm is on us now, and it is the first duty of the Government to see how we can shorten sail to weather it.

Senator Duncan-Hughes was under some misapprehension when he referred to a decision of the Loan Council under which certain amounts were credited to "Western Australia and Tasmania. They were not grants.

talk.start.para: - They were merely advances.

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE. - In the true sense, they were not even advances. Every State agreed that it would only ask from the banks an advance up to a certain amount. But "Western Australia and Tasmania intimated to the Loan Council that they could not carry out their undertaking and would be compelled to ask for advances exceeding the amounts for which they had originally undertaken to ask. As a matter of fact they intimated that they would require double what the Loan Council has now allowed them to have. The Loan Council has sanctioned these two States obtaining from the banks the amounts indicated by Senator Duncan-Hughes, but they are debts owing by the States themselves, and are not amounts contributed by the Commonwealth or by any other State. In the true sense of the term therefore, they do not compare with the grants that are made by the Commonwealth to the States. .

talk.start.para: - Is not that a departure from the Premiers plan?

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.Only to the extent of "Western Australia and Tasmania being allowed to exceed the amounts which they undertook to ask from the banks. The banks have agreed to increase the amounts originally allowed on the understanding that the balance of the two States' requirements is made up by the States themselves, either by a reduction of expenditure or by an increase of revenue.

Senator Barnes compared the present Government's proposals with those of his Government. I cannot help thinking that he is haunted by the ghosts of the past. He pointed out, for instance, that his Government had implemented the Premiers plan. The people did not condemn his Government for having done so. They condemned it because, having implemented the plan, its supporters went into the country and proceeded to condemn it, saying that at the first opportunity they would reverse it. Moreover, some of their leaders told the people that they had not abandoned the idea of an inflation of the note issue or the idea of the nationalization of banking.. The people did not believe in those panaceas. The late Government was not defeated because it had implemented the Premiers plan, but because it was still flirting with the foolish ideas of inflation and the nationalization of banking.

Senator Barnes said that Mr. Bruce is not a suitable person to send to London because he failed to raise loans in London in 1928 and 1929. The facts are that the Bruce-Page Government did raise loans in those two years. They were largely left in the hands of the underwriters it is true, but they were raised. "What happened when Mr. Scullin went to London in 1930? He announced that one of the objects of his mission was to achieve the funding of the floating debt. "Why did he fail to do ,so? Mr. Scullin himself gave the reason for his failure. He said that he had made substantial progress with his mission, but that ho failed owing to the repudiation speeches which were being made by his supporters whom he had left behind in Australia. It is on record that Mr. Scullin failed to fund the debt for the reason I have given. Whatever may be said of Mr. Bruce, it cannot be denied that he stands very high in the estimation of overseas investors. They know that when leader of a previous government his main endeavour was to place Australian finance on a sound footing. The Government of which he was the leader was not guilty of reckless borrowing. During the time it was in office the Commonwealth debt increased by only Â£13,000,000, although the increase in the national debt - Commonwealth and States- was Â£220,000,000. Reckless borrowing was not due to the action of Mr. Bruce or the government of which he was the leader. The investors in the Old Country are well aware of the fact that it was the government led by Mr. Bruce which passed legislation providing for a national debt sinking fund and control over future borrowing. After a time that government convinced the States and the people to agree to the provisions now embodied in the financial agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. When Mr. Bruce was urging the adoption of that agreement, he assumed that he was advocating an agreement between honest men, and that the parties to it would act honestly toward one another. No one could then have foreseen that a government led by a man who would publicly advocate repudiation of its debts would be returned. The financial agreement failed only to the extent that it did not make adequate provision for dealing with dishonesty.

The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) deplored the absence of proposals for public works. Has Senator Barnes lost all sense of logic? Are not our financial difficulties to-day due very largely to over-expenditure on public works? In one breath he deprecated the inability of the Commonwealth to raise money in 1929-30 under favorable terms, and in the next said we ought to raise more money. Why was not the Government able to raise money at the time to which he referred ? Plenty of money was available on the London market, but the government of the day was not able to raise a loan because Australia had overborrowed.

talk.start.para: - Will the Leader of the Senate say what he would do?

- I shall do so. The Leader of the Opposition referred to the means by which the late Government would have financed public works. It is very difficult to fully understand the late Government's financial proposals, some of which were sponsored by the Government itself and others by caucus. Let us consider the proposal put forward by the Labour caucus for providing Â£25,000,000 for public works. That is the proposal to which, I presume, the Leader of the Opposition referred. That money was to be raised by means of a forced loan from the Commonwealth Bank. Of course, the first step in that connexion was political control of the Commonwealth Bank, and the Leader of the Opposition quite innocently remarked that the Government failed to raise the money because of the action of the Senate. The action which the Senate took was to refuse to give the Government political control of the Commonwealth Bank, and thus enable it to raise a forced loan of Â£25,000,000 through that institution. In those two naive admissions the whole plan of the Government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a member is unveiled. Such a scheme might have provided some temporary relief, but I venture to say that the disaster which would have followed within a year would have brought about in Australia considerably more unemployment and misery than exist to-day. Under such a policy industry in this country would have come to a stand-still within a year.
- Is that likely to follow the adoption of a similar policy in the United States of America?

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.The two policies are not analogous.

The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) asked where we are to raise sufficient money to provide employment. The Government of which he was a member made frequent reference to the release of credits; but its members and supporters never explained what was actually meant by such an expression. I shall tell them what we mean by a release of credits. The way to provide employment is to restore confidence in the government of the country; when that is done credits are naturally released. Do honorable senators opposite read the quarterly figures published in the press with respect to the finances of Australia? If they do, they will know that when the previous Government was in office the amount of money on current account decreased, and that concurrently with that decrease the amount on fixed deposit increased. Do they realize the significance of what occurred? Confidence declined while the late Government was in power, and, consequently, profits in industry became less and less. Those companies which had their capital invested in industry found it impossible to pay dividends, and instead of capital being invested in industry and handled through current accounts, it was placed on fixed deposit at a comparatively low rate of interest. That is a striking indication of the economic condition of a country. It is essential that the vast amount of money now on fixed deposit' should be released and invested in industry. If industry can be made profitable, money will be withdrawn from fixed deposit and used in providing employment.

talk.start.para: - At whose expense?
- To the detriment of nobody.
- To the advantage of those who make profits.

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.Those engaged in the manufacture of boots, hats, or any other commodity sell their products, and nobody is injured in the process. That is what happens when industry is profitable. Larger quantities of commodities are produced, both buyer and seller benefit, and no one is injured. The Government is convinced that if industry is made profitable credits will be released, and by that means employment provided. We can commence to cure the unemployment evil not by borrowing money and increasing our interest charges, but by encouraging industry.

talk.start.para: - How does the right honorable senator suggest that industry can be made profitable?

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.Either by increasing prices, which we cannot do, or reducing the cost of production.

The Leader of the Opposition further stated that the main essential is to get the unemployed back to work. I do not agree with that contention as the only consideration. Men could be employed on unproductive works such as shifting -sand from one part of the sea coast to another; but that would not give any return for the money expended.
