The work to be found for the unemployed must be of a productive nature. This country is already labouring under the burdon of heavy interest payments on money borrowed for other than reproductive work. We cannot increase our present national debt even if we desired to do so, because money is not available. We must find some means to provide work without increasing our national debt.

talk.start.para: - How does the right honorable senator suggest that we can overcome the difficulties confronted by those, for instance, who obtained only 4 1/2d. for four tons of cabbages?

- That is a catch question which was asked by the honorable senator and those supporting him during the recent election. Those engaged in growing cabbages should realize that they should be produced and marketed only when the conditions are favorable, and not when there is likely to be a glut.

speech.para: I am not surprised to learn that the Leader of the Opposition is opposed to the Government's policy of encouraging private enterprise, because the party of which he i3 a member believes in the socialization of industry. Let the members of that party consider the position of the socialized industries in Australia to-day. Is there any prospect of our railways paying in the near future, particularly if they are conducted as they are to-day? Moreover, is there any prospect of these railways employing any more men than at present? The indications are that the number now engaged will have to be reduced. Our railways are becoming so unprofitable that out of sheer necessity many of the State Governments will have to close down unprofitable lines, and the railways ,vill provide less employment than in the past. Has any honorable senator opposite the temerity to suggest that we should construct more railways? If a loan of Â£25,000,000 had been raised on what productive work could it have been used?

talk.start.para: - The unification of the gauges.

- If the railways are to he controlled under the present system, the unification of the gauges will not do more than add to the capital cost of a system which is already overloaded to such an extent that it cannot do more than pay working expenses. When honorable senators opposite talk of the socialization of industries, why do they not tell us what other industries they propose to bring under this system.
- That is the right honorable gentleman's business.

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.We on this side do not advocate the socialization of industry. Rather do we favour private enterprise, which has always provided nearly 80 per cent, of the employment in Australia. If unemployment is to be cured, there is obviously more hope of dealing with it by encouraging private enterprise than by engaging in further government enterprises.

The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) spoke of omissions from the Governor-General's Speech. Honorable senators must have been surprised, as I was, that the honorable gentleman made no reference whatever to one of the greatest constitutional difficulties confronting Australia to-day - the failure of one State to carry out obligations into which it had solemnly entered. On the outstanding subject of our national life, the Leader of His Majesty's Opposition in this chamber had not a word to say ! For the Premier of a State who gave the Government of which Senator Barnes was a member a solemn undertaking to do certain things which he has not done, he has not a word of condemnation ! Mr. Lang gave the late Government a week's notice of the inability of New South Wales to meet its obligations. Even then the Commonwealth Government had difficulty in meeting the situation which arose ; but eventually it found the money. A condition entered into by the Premier of New South Wales, on that occasion, and recorded in the minutes of the Loan Council, was that Mr. Lang undertook in future to find the interest on both the State's internal and external obligations, and in addition, to carry out the Premiers plan to the extent of reducing his adjustable expenditure as the other States had done. On his entering into that solemn obligation Mr. Lang was re-admitted to the Loan Council. Notwithstanding that promise he notified the Commonwealth Treasurer (Mr. Lyons) on a recent Thursday evening, that his State would be unable to meet an interest liability of about Â£970,000 due overseas on the following day. The Leader of the Opposition, who was a member of the Commonwealth Government to which Mr. Lang gave his promise to pay, has not one word to say in condemnation of the action of Mr. Lang, or, indeed, any comment at all to make on the subject. I wonder whether his colleagues will adopt the same attitude. I ask leave to continue my remarks at a later hour.
Leave granted : debate adjourned.

quote.para: That the sitting of the Senate be suspended until 8.30 p.m. this day.

speech.para: It is the desire of the Government to avail itself of the opportunity presented by the presence in Canberra of practically all the Consuls-General in Australia, to tender them a complimentary dinner. The Government feels that it is in the best interests of Australia that we should show the representatives of other countries who are with us that we desire to continue friendly relations with them. This will be the only opportunity to do so, as the gentlemen concerned have to return to Sydney. This adjournment is sought in order to enable Ministers and others who have been asked to attend the function to do so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: - I have nothing further to say.

. - I agree with the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) that the mover of the Address-in-Reply (Senator Duncan-Hughes), and the seconder (Senator Brennan), handled a rather difficult task with considerable ability. I endorse also the concluding sentiments expressed in the Speech that the blessings of Divine Providence may rest upon this Parliament and the community which, for the time being, is governed by it. If the Speech is to be regarded as a true criterion of the Government's intentions, I am afraid that long before this Government vacates the treasury benches, the community will have good reason to invoke the protection of Divine Providence, because the document must be a very great disappointment to hundreds of thousands of electors throughout the Commonwealth, who were misled by the promises made during the election campaign. The Speech bears a striking resemblance to many of the United Australia party slogans published during the recent election campaign, and is just as devoid of positive proposals. It is simply a string of meaningless platitudes, and because of the absence of positive proposals, must be a source of profound disappointment, particularly to the large army of unemployed in all the States.

speech.para: In my own State, the election campaign was remarkable for the number of these alluring promises, in slogan form, in the columns of the metropolitan newspapers, and on city hoardings. In these slogans the people were told that all that was necessary to ensure a return to prosperity was to vote for a gentleman who had suddenly sprung into prominence as the leader of a newly-organized party. I have here a few examples of these promises in slogan form. Here are two - "Vote for Lyons and jobs for all." "Lyons will pay promptly, and pay in full." There was also a large poster depicting a huge army of workless people marching back to employment. I invite honorable senators supporting the Government to point to any proposal in the Governor-General's Speech calculated to honour the implied promises contained in these captions. Mr. A. Greenfell Price, the United Australia party campaign director, a very estimable gentleman, and one who, I presume, had full authority to speak on behalf of the candidates of his party, also made a number of glowing promises in advertisements published in the metropolitan newspapers. There can be no doubt on this point, because I attended a number of declarations of polls, and I heard successful United Australia party condidates eulogizing the good work which Mr. Price had done during the campaign. I am sure that many of these successful candidates must be profoundly disappointed that, up to the present, no evidence is forthcoming of the Government's intention to honour the promise made on their behalf.

talk.start.para: - Surely the honorable senator cannot expect results at once?

- Perhaps not, but we are entitled to expect some evidence of an intention to give effect to election promises. That is not to be found in the Governor-General's Speech. Other election slogans were " A vote for Lyons is a vote for work !" " Scullin and Lang failed. Let Lyons do the job; he can ". Then there was a special appeal to the women of South Australia, eleven reasons being given why they should vote for the United Australia Party candidates. I do not intend to weary the Senate by reading the whole of them, because there will be ample time, during the next three years, to remind honorable senators supporting the Government of promises made on their behalf. 1 do not know if the fact that the South African cricketers were, during part of the election campaign, playing a match against South Australia influenced the campaign director to select eleven reasons why the women should vote for United Australia Party candidates, but at all events that was the number which appeared in full page advertisements in the metropolitan newspapers. Reason No.' 6 was set forth in these terms - " The Scullin Government" renewed the sugar agreement and caused you to pay twice as much as the people of New Zealand ". "Where, in the document which was read to us yesterday, is there a suggestion that that agreement is to be revised, so that housewives in South Australia and the other States may obtain sugar at a lower price than that fixed in the agreement made by the Scullin Government with the sugar industry?
- Does the honorable senator suggest that we should repudiate the agreement?

- No ; but during the election campaign the promise was made that, if United Australia Party candidates were successful, the price of sugar would he reduced. Senator Brennan, who seconded the motion this afternoon, also made reference to this subject. In his remarks there was certainly an implication that, while the Speech contained no declaration of the Government's intention to revise the agreement, there is now a pious hope that the parties concerned will come together and agree to reduce the price of sugar below the level considered by an expert committee to be the price at which the industry could be carried on under white labour conditions. Reason No. 7, especially directed to the women of South Australia, was - " The Scullin Government raised the cost of tea by 5d. per lb." Everyone knows that the previous Government, with great reluctance, imposed a tax oh tea for revenue purposes. This Ministry and its supporters know, quite as well as the Government which imposed the tax, that, under existing financial conditions, its repeal is absolutely impossible. And yet, in the course of this debate, we have had numerous references already to this Government's honesty of purpose! We have also heard insinuations that the previous Government acted to the detriment of the people and bequeathed grave difficulties to its successors. On this point all I need say is that the Government, in 1932, found Australia in a much better position than it was when the Scullin Government took office in 1929. Other election slogans issued in South Australia were as follows: - "A prosperous New Year ! Secure it ; vote for Lyons !" " You waited two years for Scullin to do something for you ; now do something for yourself. -Vote for Lyons !" " So little done, so much to do. Vote Lyons I" " A steady government means a steady job! Give Lyons a chance!" This was the kind of propaganda that led hundreds of thousands of people to cast their votes in a certain direction on the 19th December last.

speech.para: I wish now to deal specifically with one or two of those implied promises, and I take as the first - " So little done ; so much to do ". One would have thought that, after being in office for approximately six weeks, and after the people had been told, during the election campaign, that Mr. Lyons and his party had a policy to restore financial stability, it would not be necessary to wait one day for the declaration of a positive proposal to help the workers back to work, to help the business community,' which had been struggling under adverse conditions for so many years, back to an era of profits, and our primary producers, who have been suffering so much and for so long, from low prices and droughts, back to the conditions which obtained in former years of prosperity. But we have this declaration of policy, which, as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Barnes) remarked this afternoon, contains nothing of a positive nature, and offers no hope to the unfortunate workless, many of whom on the 19th December last voted for the present Government in the belief that the promises implied by the slogans that were employed would be given effect by the Government, and that early in the new year the jobs which the Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons) was supposed to have "in the bag" waiting for the ballot-box to spring the catch would materialize in the different industries throughout Australia. Yet what do we find? In Victoria, where unemployment was decreasing during the final quarter last year, according to the latest official figures that I have obtained from the .Government Labour Exchange in that State, there was an increase in the month of January totalling 2,938. That is what is causing the disappointment to which I referred in my opening remarks.

Having read the declaration of policy, I waited until this afternoon for the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Pearce) , to furnish us with some amplification of the intentions of the Government. I expected that, being now on the other side of the chamber, he would adopt the advice which he tendered repeatedly to Labour ministers during the period that they occupied the seats of the mighty, to go ahead with the task of rehabilitation and reconstruction. But the only positive declaration that he made was that the present was not the time for an intensive legislative programme. The suggestion behind that statement was that this Parliament is shortly to be closed, and that the elected representatives of the people, who are the trustees of the interests of this country, are to return to their homes and either rusticate or spend their time in whatever way they please except in discharging the duties that they were sent to this Parliament to undertake, leaving it to the Cabinet to carry on the task of reconstruction by administrative acts. Such a declaration by the Leader of the Government does not contain very much hope for the suffering thousands in our community.

Instead of amplifying the policy of the Government, as we might reasonably have expected him to do, the right honorable gentleman went on to refer to the fact that the last Government submitted proposals designed to change the financial policy of Australia, and he condemned those proposals as being unsound. Whilst a review of the past, very often, is helpful, in coming to decisions for the future, a review of that past will not solve the problems that confront this nation unless the Government is prepared to reverse the whole of its declarations and adopt the policy to which the previous Government endeavoured to give effect. That policy, I feel convinced, provides the only solution of Australia's difficulties. It is all very well for the right honorable gentleman to condemn it. In other parts of the world the proposals that we put forward are being accepted, not condemned. Let us consider what has happened recently in that great republic, the United States of America. Within recent months we have heard in this chamber many references to what is termed " real money ". It was understood by a majority of those who listened to the debates that, took place on this subject that the term implied a reference to monetary gold. The United States of America, from one cause or another, has accumulated within recent years a huge hoard of monetary gold. It possesses nearly half of the monetary gold of the world; it has more real money than any country has possessed since the beginning of the present era of the world's history. One would think that if there were anything in the policy which the present Government professes to believe will rectify Australia's position, the United States of America would not have reached the condition of business despair, stagnation, and unemployment that exists in that country to-day. Yet we find that proportionately their unemployment is as great if not greater than ours, that their business has suffered probably more than ours, and that at last their Government has been obliged to adopt remedial measures. The President of the United States of America does not close his Parliament with the declaration that this is a time for administrative and not legislative action. According to a cable message published in the Adelaide Advertiser on the 9th December last, in his annual address at the opening of Congress, President Hoover outlined the efforts that would be made to meet unemployment and other emergencies of the depression, and said -

quote.para: Wc must put some steel beams in the foundations of our credit structure.

speech.para: The message further states -

quote.para: He drew attention to the huge deficits in government finance, and recommended the establishment of a group of discount banks throughout the country, to make loans on homes, thus encouraging home buildings, and the creation of a reconstruction finance corporation with authority to issue its own debentures and to aid a variety of businesses that were in difficulties duo to the depression.

speech.para: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has since been created. What are its articles of association ? They are, " That the credit of the American nation, to the extent of Â£450,000,000, is to be used in the form of fiduciary debentures to liquefy and cause to flow the credit of the United States of America, to enable private banks that have been closed because of the freezing of their securities, due to the depression, to secure a supply of cash to re-open, thus enabling businesses to be restarted and employment to be provided." That is precisely the policy which the Labour party endeavoured to enact while it occupied the Government benches ; but this Senate was responsible for preventing it from being given effect.

The suggestion made by the last Government, at the instance of the ex-Treasurer (Mr. Theodore), was something on the lines of a managed currency, something in the nature of controlled inflation, the barometer of control to be commodity prices. What is happening in America to-day as the result of the release of Â£450,000,000 worth of credit through the National Reconstruction Corporation? Commodity prices have risen, industrial and other securities have firmed, and there is at the moment in New York a jio te of confidence which was absent in December last before this action was taken. Had similar action been taken in Australia when it was proposed by the last Government, there would today be a stronger note of confidence, greater employment, and more security for the business undertakings of this country. A managed currency is condemned by our honorable friends opposite. Let us contrast their attitude with that of a gentleman who, according to the positions he has held in the past and the office he now holds, is entitled to speak with some authority on this question. I refer to Mr. Reginald McKenna, a former Chancellor of the Exchequer in Great Britain, who is now chairman of directors of one of the greatest banks in the Old Country, the Midland Bank. According to a cable message that was published in the Adelaide Mail on the 30th January last, addressing the annual meeting of shareholders of the Midland Bank on the 29th idem, Mr. McKenna said -

quote.para: Either we must have a soundly-managed gold standard, which can only be secured by well-ordered international action, or we must definitely abandon gold and rely upon a managed standard without any metallic basis. In either event one thing is certain; the art of monetary management must be relied on more and more to obviate such a catastrophe to economic life as we are witnessing to-day. Our experience in the last few months has taught us which of the alternatives mentioned we should choose.

talk.start.para: - That is not government management.

- Mr. McKenna does not declare against government management. I remind the honorable senator that the currency of Great Britain to-day is largely a government managed currency, that there is a fiduciary currency of, I think, Â£2S5,000,000, which has been issued under authority conferred by the Parliament in the Bank Act. When I last consulted that act the fiduciary note issue authorized by it amounted to Â£260,000,0000; hut power is conferred upon the administration to increase the issue in times of stress, provided that, after a certain period, should the notes not be redeemed, the authority of Parliament must be secured. When the financial holocaust descended on Great Britain last year, that power was exercised, and the issue was increased to the extent of Â£25,000,000. I have seen no mention of the redemption of that additional amount. To-day two-thirds of the currency of Great Britain is fiduciary. It is a government-managed currency issued by the Bank of England under the authority of the British Parliament. Mr. McKenna says that unless a better international agreement can be arrived at for the rational use of credit, the nations must depart from the metal standard altogether and adopt for the carrying on of all activities of business a managed currency provided by the financial systems of to-day. Speaking with experience as Chancellor of the Exchequer of Great Britain, in which capacity he was practically responsible for the control of the fiduciary currency, he could have meant nothing less than an extension of the currency provisions of the Bank of England Act with which he is familiar, aud under which he has worked both as Chancellor of the Exchequer and as director of one of the greatest banking corporations of Great Britain.

speech.para: The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Pearce) said that the Government, in some mysterious way, proposes to release credit by the creation of confidence, which he alleges the late Government destroyed, and in order to prove his assertion, he quoted figures relating to the fixed deposits in current accounts in the trading banks of Australia. He showed that during recent years there had been a tremendous increase in the amount on fixed deposit compared with the amount on current account, proving that there had been a tendency to tie up the nation's working capital. He laid the blame for this at the door of the late Government. If the right honorable gentleman would look at the Commonwealth Statistician's figures, he would find that this tying up of the nation's working capital occurred during the regime of previous governments of which he was an illustrious member. In 1921, the amount at current account in the trading banks and the Commonwealth Bank was Â£128,000,000, and the amount on fixed deposit, Â£119,500,000. The excess of deposits at current account over the amount on fixed deposit was Â£8,500,000. Eight years later, in 1929, the amount at current account was Â£127,500,000, and the amount on fixed deposit, Â£202,500,000, the excess in favour of fixed deposits being Â£75,000,000. If an increase in the amount on fixed deposit compared with the amount at current account can be attributed to the destruction of confidence that destruction of confidence must have been brought about by the Governments of which the right honorable senator was a member, because in the eight years from 1921 to 1929 the nation's working capital was tied up to the extent of Â£83,000,000. During the two years a Labour Government was in office the amount at current account dropped from Â£127,500,000 to Â£91,000,000, and the amount on fixed deposit increased from Â£202,500,000 to Â£210,500,000, an increase of Â£8,000,000, or Â£4,000,000 a year, a much lower rate than when anti-Labour governments were in power. The reduction in the amount at current account is easily explainable. It is due to the depreciation in the value of the securities held by the banks against overdrafts. These figures by no means substantiate the case made out by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On the contrary, they destroy it. I venture to say that to-day the people of Australia are wondering why they did not listen a little more attentively and kindly to the words of wisdom they heard from responsible members of the Labour party when a mandate was sought for them to give effect to a policy which would have improved the condition of the majority of the citizens of Australia.

talk.start.para: - You can do it once only.

- You can do it, and can keep on doing it provided you insist that the credit released is used for the creation of new wealth or for giving to the community some service for which it can afford to pay. Under a managed currency that would be the limit. As a. matter of fact, it is the limit today, but with this difference, that to-day our currency is controlled. After all, the note issue plays a very infinitesimal part in our business transactions. As already pointed out to-day, those transactions are mainly carried out by cheques, and the volume of cheques is controlled to an appreciable extent by the value of securities lodged with the banks against overdrafts. In good times, when prices are high, the amount of currency of that nature is, of course, increased materially. All that Labour suggested was that as an antidote to the depression, the nation should take the responsibility off the should crs of the private banks. I do not blame the banks for restricting credit - I have amplified this before - they must protect their depositors and shareholders - but in Australia there is work of a profitable nature to be done. There are types of production which could be increased. Take small-farm production as a case iu point. As the result of recent tariff activities in Great Britain, Australia has been given a very decided advantage over Scandinavian countries for the supply of a very substantial proportion of the butter and other small-farm products which the people of Great Britain consume, and there is opportunity at the moment for the Commonwealth Government, in cooperation with the State Governments, to stimulate this kind of production which can be produced in Australia and sold at a profit in Great Britain. That was the type of work to encourage which Labour suggested the credit of Australia should be used. We also suggested that it should be used to enable people to be absorbed in industry and for businesses to be built up.

speech.para: If there is one thing more than another that the present Government, according to declarations of policy during the election campaign, wishes to maintain, it is the inviolability of the Premiers plan and the credit of Australia by the prompt payment of Australia's overseas commitments. I shall deal first with the inviolability of the Premiers plan. Early in the history of this Government a conference with State Ministers was held in Melbourne, at which a vital decision was reached. That decision was that the States of Western Australia and Tasmania should be permitted to depart from the pledges given when the Premiers' plan was adopted, and their total Budgetary de fecit was permitted to be increased by a substantial amount. The

Premier of South Australia who, has been a very consistent supporter of the Premiers plan, has roundly condemned the attitude of the Commonwealth Government in this connexion. According to a report published in the Adelaide Advertiser on this subject, he said -

quote.para: I have always been a keen advocate of two things in connexion with Australia's financial position. One is that the smaller Status should bc relieved of their disabilities under federation, and the other is the Premiers plan, as the best means for Australia to rectify her financial position. The resolution passed by the Loan Council is a departure from 'both of those principles. It is a loan to Western Australia and Tasmania to meet revenue expenditure. It will not relieve them of their difficulties, and they will have further trouble in making up the amount of increased deficits not met by these temporary loans. In effect, this is a departure from the Premiers plan.

speech.para: He went on to say that the better course would be for the whole nation to shoulder the responsibility by way of a disabilities grant if any State failed to meet its commitments through no fault of its own. The Advertiser in a leading article on the 2nd February, 1932, shows that Tasmania and Western Australia have not done so much as some of the other States to keep within the Premiers plan. That plan provided that two things must be done to bring about budgetary equilibrium for all the States in Australia. One was that iu order to get as close as possible to that equilibrium, economies should 'be effected to the maximum, and revenue should be raised to the maximum. The various States adopted different methods of effecting economies and raising revenue, and with two or three exceptions they have substantially succeeded. South Australia, which probably had a more difficult situation to face than any other State, succeeded in, reducing its budgetary deficit by those means, and I venture to say - the Advertiser says it deliberately in its leading article, which is too long for me to read - that Western Australia could also have succeeded if it had been prepared to take the steps which South Australia was compelled to take. There is an informative quotation in the Advertiser article, comparing the positions of farmers in Western Australia and South Australia. The comparison is between a South Australian farm of 1,300 acres situated 30 miles from the seaport, and a Western Australian farm of 1,400 acres situated 170 miles from the seaport. The land tax on the South Australian farm is Â£S2, compared with Â£7 on the Western Australian farm. The district council rates on the South Australian farm total Â£15, compared with Â£7 on the Western Australian farm. Leaving out such questions as education and the like, we come to the important factor of railway freights. The outward freight on wheat from the South Australian farm is 4d. a bushel. It is also 4d. a bushel from the Western Australian farm, more than five times further away from the seaport. The inward freight on superphosphate to the South Australian farm is lis. a ton; to the Western Australian farm it is only 5s. a ton. The farmers of South Australia have been forced to accept these burdens under the Premiers' plan. If the compact made in Melbourne is to be honoured and justice is to be meted out to all the States, the people of Western Australia should accept a burden at least somewhat approximating that which the people of South Australia have been compelled to accept. I need not give the comparative figures on taxation. They have already been given by Senator Duncan-Hughes. I content myself by pointing out that the taxation in Western Australia is 50 per cent, of that paid in South Australia, and that in Tasmania it is 60 per cent, of that paid in South Australia.

talk.start.para: - What about (lie ability of the States to pay?
- Taking the ability to pay. the position is accentuated in the case of Western Australia.

speech.para: Senn tor Herbert Hays. - But not in the case of Tasmania.

talk.start.para: - I admit that the taxable capacity of Tasmania is the lowest in the Commonwealth. I think it is about 50 per cent, of the Australian average. That of South Australia is 75 per cent, of the Australian average, but that of Western Australia is equal to the Australian average, and is, therefore, 25 per cent, greater than that of South Australia. In that respect Western Australia is a worse offender than Tasmania.
- How does the honorable senator arrive at the taxable capacity of a State?
- The figures from which I am quoting have been compiled by the economic experts, who were largely responsible for the Premiers plan.
- Where did the honorable senator obtain them?
- They have been compiled by Professor Giblin and other professors, and were published in the report on the disabilities of South Australia recently presented to this Parliament.

speech.para: New South Wales, which did not adhere to the proposals embodied in the Premiers plan, has been ostracized. As finance is not available to that State to enable it to carry on, it has been forced to default.

talk.start.para: - It has elected -to default.
- The South Australian Advertiser puts the position very clearly in this way -

quote.para: If only in so far as it made fish of one State and flesh of another, the Loan Council blundered yesterday, when, by a majority vote, and as it seems, without adequate inquiry, it granted special concessions to Western Australia and Tasmania.

speech.para: That is the opinion expressed by a newspaper which supported this Government during the recent election campaign, and it uses terms much stronger than those which I would employ. It condemns the action of the Commonwealth Government which was responsible for the decision of the Loan Council so strongly stigmatized in the newspaper from which I have just quoted. The right honorable the Leader of the Senate said that New South Wales elected to default. What would have happened to Western Australia and Tasmania had special consideration not been given to those States? They, too, would have been forced to default. Where is the difference ?

talk.start.para: - They honoured their undertakings.

- It is all very well to blame the Premier of New South Wales (Mr. Lang) for the default of New South Wales. Whether we agree or disagree with Mr. Lang's methods we have to admit that for the moment he is in a position of power in New South. Wales, and that any action taken against Mr. Lang affects the State and its people. The electors of New South Wales are entitled to the same consideration as given to those of Western Australia and Tasmania regardless of who may be the Premier of New South Wales, or Prime Minister of the Commonwealth. Owing to the way in which the matter has been handled by this Government, it is not default on the part of New South Wales, but default by the Commonwealth. The late Government was in a similar position, but it did not permit the Commonwealth to default. It paid the amount due by New South Wales, and arranged to collect the money later.
- On the condition that it would not occur again:

- This Government refused to provide the Â£500,000 which New South Wales required to meet its interest commitments, and when it discovered that it had made a mistake, hastened to assure the bondholders abroad that their interest would be paid whether it was or was not collected from the New South Wales Government. In the meantime irreparable damage had been done to Australia's credit. In one day the value of Australian bonds in London and New York dropped to the extent of Â£23,500,000. Such a drop seriously affected cautious bondholders who could not afford to take any risk, and benefited the speculators who could afford to take a chance and who consequently made a " rake-off ".

speech.para: The Government has also been condemned by the Industrial Australian and Mining Standard of the 4th February of this year, which usually supports its policy. It states -

quote.para: Under the Financial Agreement the Commonwealth assumed absolute responsibility for Mie whole of Australia's debts. If the Commonwealth, therefore, permits any State to default in one of its engagements, that "default instantly assumes the complexion of default By the Commonwealth. Our external creditors are fully aware of the unalterable fact.

The Commonwealth Government intends eventually to make good Mr. Lang's default. It has said so. It will pay Mr. Lang's overseas creditors in full after it has clipped Mr. tang's wings. ~ Unhappily, it will pay Mr.

Lang's debt too late to save our national honour from disgrace if it further delays payment. For Mr. Lang's debt is Australia's debt, and if Mr. Lang defaults, we default. Australia's quarrel with Mr. Lang is no concern of our external creditors. If Australia makes them pawns in a game of politics (instruments to coerce Mr. Lang), all the decent people of Australia will suffer equally with Mr. Lang in the esteem of the world.

speech.para: That is what has been objected to by the people abroad and by such institutions as the Westminster Bank and the Chase National Bank which, when approached on the subject, made similar declarations to those published in the Australian press.

It was most unfortunate, they said, that the Lyons-Lang controversy could not be settled within Australia. The Commonwealth's credit already had been adversely affected. This was more important than the Â£500,000, which Mr. Lang sought from the Loan Council.

talk.start.para: - How would the honorable senator feel if he held some of the bonds?
- I should feel that I had been unjustly treated by the Commonwealth which under the financial agreement is responsible for meeting the interest on the bonds.
- Does the honorable senator endorse the statement that we are responsible?
- We are.
- The passage which the honorable senator read does not say so.
- The paragraph in the Industrial Australian and Mining Standard reads -

quote.para: Under the financial agreement the Commonwealth assumed absolute responsibility for the whole of Australia's debts.

speech.para: It means that we assume responsibility for New South Wales as we do in connexion with the other States.

I am opposed to the Government's proposal to abolish the Public Accounts Committee, and I hope that the financial policy of the Government is not to be judged by actions such as it proposes to take in this connexion. The Commonwealth Parliament as the trustee of the people of the Commonwealth appoints a cabinet to act as its board of directors and to retain some such measure of control over the finances as can be afforded by the assistance of a Public Accounts Committee. Although we have been informed that the committtee is to be abolished in order to effect economy, we find that the parliaments of other countries are strengthening their control over financial affairs by appointing additional committees or increasing the powers of existing bodies. In a recent report on the financial position of Tasmania - a State which the Prime Minister represents - the Auditor-General of that State insists upon the imperative necessity of appointing a Public Accounts Committee to safeguard the State's finances. Instead of abolishing the Commonwealth Public Accounts Committee as is proposed, the Government should alter the constitution of the committee and allow it to function for the objects for which it was established, which were so clearly outlined by that great Australian, the late Lord Forrest, in 1913. Before the Government does anything in the direction of abolishing the committee it should recognize that which was recognized by the previous Government when a measure to reduce the personnel, of the committee was under consideration last year. In that measure a clause was inserted to enable 'the committee to conclude an important investigation on which it was then engaged into the parliamentary control and procedure in relation to the public finances of the Commonwealth, the form in which Estimates and budget-papers and other financial statements are presented to and dealt with by Parliament, and the desirability of uniform methods of accounts for the Commonwealth and the States. It was decided by the Government of the day that the Public Accounts Committee should be permitted "to complete that inquiry before any alteration in its personnel was made, but owing to the dissolution of Parliament, the bill was not finally passed. The committee obtained evidence from eminent authorities, compiled a mass of information, and had it been permitted to complete its report would have been able to recommend means by which substantial improvements could he made in the keeping and presentation of Commonwealth accounts and the possibility of very substantial savings would have been disclosed. Recommendations would also have been submitted concerning an alter- tion in the personnel of the committee, to enable it to function along the lines of a similar committee of the House of Commons, which co-opts the assistance of experts from the Audit Department and Treasury. Before taking, any action to abolish the committee the Government should permit it to be reconstituted to enable the valuable evidence secured and which is ready for- presentation to Parliament to be made available. I trust the Government will give this matter its serious consideration.

In conclusion, I desire to refer to the statement of the Leader of the Government in the Senate that the Government cannot find employment for all the people of this country. That is the task of private enterprise. I venture to suggest that the late Government did more to assist private enterprise in providing employment than any other government has done. It afforded protection to Australian industries which resulted, not only in the Australian people manufacturing those things which they required instead of purchasing them from abroad, but also in converting a huge adverse trade balance into a favorable trade balance. By that means it assisted in maintaining national solvency during the most difficult period in the nation's history. If this Government is able, at the closing of its term of office, to point to a similar record, it will have achieved something of which it may he proud.

talk.start.para: . - Those honorable senators who moved and seconded the Address-in-Reply made the best of the meagre materials provided for them in the Governor-General's Speech." I wish to refer to some of the statements which have been made during this debate, but I have no intention of traversing the whole Speech. Senator Brennan stated that the absence from the Speech of many proposals for legislative enactment was all to the good. He pointed out that every law curtailed to some extent the liberty of the individual, and that consequently the less legislation the better. With that wise generality I heartily agree; but under the existing social system, and probably also under previously existing social systems, there are groups of individuals whose instincts lead them to abuse the freedom they possess, and to trespass on the freedom of others. Laws are therefore necessary to curb their rapacity. Because of the development of the capitalistic system, these predatory individuals, who live by exploiting the people generally, have become so numerous and skilled in the art of breaking through, or evading the law, that almost the whole of the time of parliament is taken up in either enacting new laws or amending existing laws in order to deal with their pernicious activities. So long as the capitalistic system exists so long will parliaments be required to enact legislation to prevent the worst phases of that system from dominating the whole system. There has been too much legislation in some directions. Forty years ago, when I was connected with a radical journal, I advocated that for every new law placed on the statute-book one or more old laws should be repealed. By that means I hoped that our legislation would bc brought within practical limits. We have to enact legislation to-day almost entirely because the existing system makes it easier for men to do right than wrong, to rob their neighbours than to live by honest toil. Until the capitalistic system has been abolished none of the proposed remedies for the existing evils will be of more than a superficial nature.

speech.para: I listened with interest to the Leader of the Senate (Senator Pearce) when he roundly condemned the socialization of industry. The right honorable gentleman stated that the chief reason for our heavy indebtedness was that we have so many nationalized, or socialized, services. He specially mentioned our non-paying railways. As on previous occasions my remarks in this connexion seem to have been misunderstood, I shall to-night endeavour to make my meaning perfectly plain. The nationalization of industries, such as the railways, telegraphs and telephones, is not in any respect socialism. The socialization of industries as now advocated does not mean that governments are to make a piecemeal acquisition of public services, or of industries; nor does it mean that we shall borrow money to buy manufactories, or float loans in order to extend our railway systems. The socialization of industry means the establishment of socialism as an organized method of breaking away completely from the present system.

talk.start.para: - How would the honorable senator bring it about?
- I do not propose to present to honorable senators to-night a fully developed scheme for the inauguration of socialism. Socialism will be established as the result of circumstances.
- Such as those which exist in Russia to-day.
- I do not suppose that the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator McLachlan) knows as much about Russia as I do.
- Probably I do not.

- The Minister's admission denies him the right to criticize conditions in Russia. I shall not attempt in this speech to deal with conditions in Russia; but it is beyond refutation that although the world is richer to-day in real wealth than ever before, there is more suffering and direr poverty than it has previously known. Surely those facts are a sufficient indictment of the present system !
- It has not yet been established that they are facts.

- I am prepared to bring forward evidence in support of my statement. The Leader of the Government also said that only by encouraging private enterprise could we hope for any improvement of existing conditions. One naturally thinks of the United States of America - that great citadel of individualism - when seeking the results of private enterprise, because in that country socialism is taboo, and trade unionism is so poorly organized that even its leaders confess that only slightly more than 5 per cent, of the workers " there are organized. In the United States of America, moreover, there is no political Labour party in existence, so that individualism and private enterprise there are unrestricted. The railways of that country are owned by private companies, as are also its telegraphs and telephones, and other social services; yet the latest reports available show that between 8,000,000 and 10,000,000 persons in that country are unemployed, while many millions more are only partially employed. That is the state of affairs in the home of private enterprise, one of the finest countries in the world, which has a home market of 120,000,000 people.
- I would rather he unemployed in the United States of America than employed in Russia

- The people in the United States of America who are unemployed are out of work largely because of conditions over which they have no control. Neither they nor the workers of Russia have any choice as to their domicile. The United States of America has incurred no heavy indebtedness because of allegedly foolish socialistic experiments, as is said to be the case in Australia. Although it has an accumulated gold reserve of Â£1,000,000,000, the United States of America is unable to escape from its financial difficulties. Only a week, or two ago President Hoover admitted that his country's deficit at the end of the current financial year will be about Â£424,000,000. In the face of these facts, which are indisputable, honorable senators opposite laud private enterprise while at the same time condemning anything that has a taint of socialism. In roy opinion the term " socialization of industry" is an unfortunate one; I prefer " the establishment of socialism "
- Or sovietism.

- The word " soviet " is a Russian word meaning " council " ; it has reference to the organizing of affairs according to a definite plan rather than going on in a " hotch-potch way " as we do in this country.

speech.para: The capitalistic system has hopelessly failed. Even before the war it was doomed; the war hastened its end. The reason is plain. Invention, discovery and technical equipment have advanced to such an extent that competent investigators have affirmed that in any highly industrialized country the needs of the community for a year could be produced in two months. This would mean that machines would be idle for ten months out of twelve, although the amount of work required to produce the commodities might be spread over the full term.

talk.start.para: - Soviet Russia is straining every nerve to do the same.

- I am not speaking about Russia. The fact remains that if we continue producing a much larger volume of goods than we can consume, we must necessarily throw a larger proportion of machinery into idleness and, to that extent, reduce the return on invested capital. Honorable senators opposite will see that I have a tender regard for the interests of the capitalists in this matter. The invention of up-to-date machinery and the perfection of technical equipment and chemical research enable manufacturers to produce so heavily, that, from time to time, a glut is caused in the markets of not only one country, but also in the markets of the world, with the result that prices- for those commodities fall rapidly, mills and factories are forced to close or work half time, and thousands of operatives are thrown on the industrial scrapheap Being then, unemployed, their purchasing power is nil. Consequently, there is further depression in business, leading to further unemployment. So the vicious circle i3 continued. In all industries machinery is now doing the work formerly done by men. "When I was a lad working with others in the harvest field, we were required to bind and remove the sheaves cut by the reaping machines, so that they would not be trampled upon by the farm horses' on their next round. That work gave employment to a large number of men. Now harvesting is done in one operation. The displacement of human labour in that one occupation can be multiplied in every direction. It is not wide of the truth to say that man power in industry has been displaced by machinery to such an extent in recent years that one-half of the adult workers of the world could be drowned in the Pacific without any appreciable effect upon the output of modern machinery under mass production methods. And this process of mechanizing production is going on at an accelerated rate.
- But it is not the true cause of the present world problem.
- If human beings are thrown out of employment, the market for the sale of products must necessarily be restricted.
- England is supporting more people to-day than she did 100 years ago, when little or no machinery was used in industry.

- England was the first country to utilize machinery in the textile industries and later in the heavy industries. This gave her the command of the world's markets, and as she had been for centuries the leading maritime nation, she reaped enormous profits from the sea carriage of her manufactured products to other countries and the transport of raw materials required by British industries.

speech.para: Later, when other countries followed her example and introduced machinery in industry, her position became increasingly difficult, and now she cannot maintain all her people in reasonable comfort. Unemployment is increasing, notwithstanding the return to power recently of a Government of which the present Commonwealth administration is a weak imitation. But for the migration of her surplus population, Great Britain would have been a mass of starving humanity long ago. Being also the great financial centre of the world she has levied tribute, in the form of interest upon loans to other civilized and semi-civilized countries. By this means she obtained spheres of influence for trade which gave her control of an unlimited supply of raw materials produced in cheap labour countries and enabled her to maintain an aristocracy of labour at home. But that time has gone.

The Speech makes reference to world competition which prevents an increase in commodity prices by means of which we hope to restore prosperity to this country. Every nation is now in commercial and financial difficulties. Some are actually bankrupt, but are being allowed to carry on by the goodwill of their creditors. The world war mortgaged the production of future generations and added to the impoverishment that already existed in all the older countries. The condition of their people has now become unendurable. The popular remedy is to reduce wages in industry, lengthen the hours of labour, and otherwise take what steps are possible to bring down costs of production. Great Britain complains that she cannot afford to pay the Australian rate of wages. On the Continent Germany declares that she cannot pay the rate of wages obtaining in British industries. Other competing nations make similar complaints. Wages in the far-eastern countries are about one-tenth of the wages paid in Great Britain. This means, of course, that the purchasing power of the people in the Far East has fallen to such an extent that they are unable to obtain the commodities of which they stand in urgent need. Consequently, European manufacturers have to seek other markets, and are compelled to reduce wages. If this vicious circle is allowed to continue, finally the condition of the workers in European countries will be brought down to the coolie level of India, China, and Japan.We who represent the workers feel that we must struggle against these forces which, if unchecked, will destroy the living standards of our people. We declare that wo cannot afford to wait for legislation. We might as well wait for the millennium. Consequently, we are determined to main tain the struggle and, if necessary, will carry the war into the enemy's camp. This is the class struggle.

talk.start.para: - I thought the honorable senator's claim was that the workers had nothing to lose.

- Our claim is that we have not got what we ought to have, and it is our bounden duty to ourselves and those dependent upon us to struggle, in every possible way, to retain what little we have, and to use every opportunity to fight for more. So long as the capitalistic system exists, so long will the class struggle continue. This does not mean, as some people endeavour mistakenly and others falsely, to represent, that we are preaching class hatred. That is not what we advocate. We declare that there must be this class struggle while the system of production for profit by wage labour exists, and while wage labour is continually being ground down to the lowest level of subsistence. This class struggle has its roots in the existing social order, and must continue while those conditions prevail.
- What about the profits made in Lang's lottery? Are they legitimate?
- The right honorable gentleman is dealing with trivialities.
- 1 thought the lottery system was part of the Lang plan.
- I have had no hand or voice in the establishment of the lottery in New South Wales. In any event, Mr. Lang is not a professed socialist.

speech.para: Senator Brennan made some reference to the spirit of revolution which appears to be evident in some parts of the Commonwealth. I remind honorable senators that the word simply means a complete change, though not necessarily a complete change in the social order. We may speak of a revolution in industry or the revolution which has taken place in navigation since the days of the old sailing vessels. The term " revolution ", in its application to the ushering in of socialism, does not necessarily imply the adoption of violence. It means a complete change, instead of the haphazard nationalization of industries. The railway systems, for example, do not manufacture their own rolling-stock, but purchase their requirements from private enterprise. Under the existing system State undertakings are inextricably mixed up with private enterprise, and, consequently, can furnish no criterion as to the manner in which socialism as a system would work. Such a system cannot be established piecemeal; it must either be thoroughly organized or remain in the clouds. I want to make it perfectly clear that I and those who think with me do not necessarily mean that such a revolution should be accompanied by violence.

talk.start.para: - On one occasion in this chamber the honorable senator said that he was prepared to either kill or be killed in a revolution.

- I would say it again if necessary. There will be no need to use force if the possessing class are animated by a spirit of sweet reasonableness; but should they decline to realize that we are passing through a period of transition, that the old system is damned irretrievably and must be replaced by another; should they set their faces stubbornly against the change and, like Pharaoh with the children of Israel, harden their hearts and use all their political and social influence to repress those who are endeavouring to bring about the change, they will be responsible for whatever occurs. I believe that many of the best educated and some of the most prosperous people in the community are convinced, as I am, that socialism must be the next step taken by humanity to save itself from destruction. If, through self-interest, those who have vested interests refuse even to consider these matters, they will have only themselves to blame for what occurs.

speech.para: The French revolution was not planned and organized, but waa the natural outcome of the infamous conditions to which the people were subjected. Similarly, any revolution that may arise either here or elsewhere, will be the fruits of the existing conditions, and not the result of any scheming or plotting in underground cellars. The capitalistic system offers no permanent hope of a recovery from the position in which humanity finds itself to-day. As each country becomes industrialized, it becomes a competitor of other countries instead of a user of their products, and thus the area in which foreign trade can be acquired is constantly contracting. There are, of course, many commodities for the production of which some countries are peculiarly adapted, but, generally speaking, the. constant mechanizing of different communities is adding to the number of competitors and restricting the area in which they may compete. The friction which arises from this acute and intense competition accumulates, until eventually it reaches the exploding point and warfare is the result. War is as much the natural fruit of the capitalistic system as crime is the fruit of poverty and ignorance. So long as that system exists we shall always be either at war or preparing for it.

The pious wish is expressed in the Speech of the Governor-General that' the Disarmament Conference will be successful. I venture the opinion that it has not a million to one chance of being successful. The seven greatest powers to-day are spending upon armaments annually over Â£14,000,000 more than they spent in 1913. The present trouble in China proves that when any great nation attempts to impose its will on a weaker nation, the League of Nations is powerless. I do not say that either country is entirely blameless. The fact remains, however, that a state of war exists, the only factor absent being an official declaration, and that it has broken out in spite of the pacts, compacts and other undertakings that have been entered into during the last few years. While the capitalist system prevails, war is the inevitable outcome of a strong nation being hemmed in, with a rapidly increasing population, and a shortage of raw materials. She must endeavour to expand so as to obtain the raw materials she needs, and the space that her people require.

I admit that a temporary alleviation of the position in which we find ourselves at the present time may be effected; but the prevailing conditions must inevitably recur unless the fundamental causes of them are removed. We are told that only by living within our income and reducing the cost of products can we restore confidence and sot in motion the locked-up private enterprise that awaits development. Honorable senators opposite claim to possess the quality of honesty. Why have they not the common honesty to admit that what they propose is a reduction of wages and a lengthening of hours? I heard the United Australia party candidate in the recent East Sydney by-election campaign say that it was better for two men to receive Â£2 a week each than for one to receive Â£4, and the other to be idle. Fining down the matter to one individual is most misleading. Doubtless, were I a man of independent means, and I wanted to engage labour to erect a summer-house or in some other way to beautify my estate, and I could obtain the services of two men for Â£3 a week each, it would be cheaper for me to employ them than to pay one man Â£6 a week. If such a practice became general, however, the purchasing power of the people would be so far reduced that it would make an enormous difference to the life of the community. The policy of the party which is now in power in this Parliament is opposed, not only to natural justice, but also to elementary commonsense. If cheap labour were the solution of the unemployed difficulty, there would be no unemployed in China, India or Japan, where males work for1s. a day, women for half that amount, and children for even less. Yet' in those countries millions of the population arc unemployed. It is indisputable that if low wages and long hours were factors in promoting prosperity they would be the most prosperous communities on earth. It stands to reason that if Now South Wales abolished the 44-hour week and reverted to the 48-hour week, fewer men would be required for the work that is offering. The whole object involved in a lengthening of hours is to dispense with some portion of the labour that is at present engaged. I ask leave to continue my remarks on another occasion.
Leave granted ; debate adjourned.

debate.para: Rabbit Netting and Poisons: Exemption from Sales Tax and Primage Duties.
Motion (by Senator Sir George Pearce) proposed -
That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - I draw the attention of the Government to the necessity for exempting from the sales tax and primage duties rabbit netting and rabbit poisons. The Leader of the Senate (Senator Pearce) has been in Western Australia lately, and I believe realizes the fact that the number of rabbits has increased alarmingly in every portion of that State ; yet the people are called upon to pay very heavy primage duties and sales tax when they have occasion to purchase the rabbit netting and poisons which are necessary to deal with the pest. I have received from the Road Board Association of Western Australia, which represents the whole of the rural areas of that State, a letter on the subject. I believe that, owing to the nature of the season through which wo have passed, a similar position exists in other parts of the Commonwealth. The letter reads -

speech.para: I beg to advise that at the meeting of the executive committee of the above association, held on the 27th January, a number of communications were received from country road boards requesting relief from the imposition of the sales tax and primage duty on rabbit poisons, wire netting, &c, used largely in the destruction of rabbits.

The committee resolved that each Western Australian representative in the Federal Houses of Parliament should be asked to take such action, and use all the pressure possible on the federal authorities, for the purpose of assisting the farmers generally, who are finding the increased expenditure, due to the imposition referred to, to very burdensome, and I am desired to express the wish that you maybe able to assist in the removal of the taxes referred to on behalf of all primary producers.

For your information I am to add that owing to the large number of abandoned properties and unattended Crown lands, rabbits have been very much on the increase this year, rendering the task of those who remain on the land in keeping down the rabbits very difficult and costly. Where the settler has not wire netted his holding the task is almost hopeless, and the cost of netting is almost prohibitive by reason of the high charges on it.
Trusting you will be able to afford a measure of help on the lines requested,
I am yours faithfully,

item.label: K.
item.para: H. Rosman, Secretary.

speech.para: Senator Rae. - What are the duties?

talk.start.para: -We permit rabbit-proof netting to come in from England free of duty, but importations from foreign countries pay a duty of Â£2 a ton. In the present circumstances, I think that that duty might well be remitted. There is also 25 per cent. exchange on the purchase price, and then come the most objectionable features, a primage duty of 10 per cent., and a sales tax of 6 per cent. The Governmentthus extorts 16 per cent. duty on a commodity which it says should be imported free of duty from Great Britain in order to help the primary producers. In regard to rabbit poisons, the primage duty is 10 per cent. in the case of phosphorus, which is mostly used. I understand that it is 4 per cent. on cyanide, which is principally used for other purposes. Practically every farmer in the wheat belt of Western Australia, and persons in other parts of the State make extensive use of rabbit poison.
- What is the effect on the price of rabbit-proof fencing?

- These charges add 41 per cent. to the landed cost. I hope that the Government knowing that these charges hear very heavily on the primary producers will remit the primage duty and sales tax on items, particularly on rabbit-proof netting, which are required by the farmers to enable them to get rid of the fearful pest of rabbits.

[10.17]. - As a representative of Western Australia, I have also received the letter which the honorable senator has read, and have forwarded it to the Minister for Trade and Customs, making representations on the same lines as those advanced by the honorable senator. I will see that the honorable senator's remarks are brought under the notice of the Minister and the Treasurer.
